Two New Coordination Polymers with Co(II) and Mn(II): Selective Gas Adsorption and Magnetic Studies

    Two New Coordination Polymers with Co(II) and Mn(II): Selective Gas Adsorption and Magnetic Studies

    • Rashmi A. Agarwal†
      • , 
    • Arshad Aijaz†§
      • , 
    • Musheer Ahmad†
      • , 
    • E. Carolina Sañudo‡
      • , 
    • Qiang Xu§
      • , and 
    • Parimal K. Bharadwaj*†
    View Author Information
    † Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur 208016, India
    ‡ Departament de Quımica Inorganica, Universitat de Barcelona, Diagonal, 647, 08028-Barcelona, Spain
    § National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan
    *E-mail: pkb@iitk.ac.in
    Cite this: Cryst. Growth Des. 2012, 12, 6, 2999–3005
    Publication Date (Web):April 26, 2012

    Publication History

    • Revised23 April 2012

    Supporting Info (2)»Supporting Information Supporting Information
    SUBJECTS:
    • Metals,
    Crystal Growth & Design
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A novel bifurcated ligand 3,5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DBIBN) has been synthesized, which reacts with Co(II) and Mn(II) salts to form new coordination polymers {[Co2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·9H2O}n (1) and {[Mn3(DBIBA)6]}n (2), (DBIBA = 3,5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzoate), in which DBIBN get hydrolyzed into DBIBA under solvothermal conditions. Both the complexes have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography (XRD), IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, thermogravimetry, and X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD). Complex 1 is a 3D coordination polymer composed of binuclear Co(II) units, having (4,6) connected net. On the other hand, complex 2 is a layered structure with trinuclear Mn(II) units, which has 4-connected 44sql topology. TGA and PXRD measurements show that the framework 1 is stable after desolvation. Desolvated framework 1 showed selective adsorption of CO2 over N2, H2, and Ar. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements show that complex 1 exhibits weak antiferromagnetic behavior.

    Synopsis

    Two novel coordination polymers have been synthesized solvothermally using a bifurcated ligand DBIBN. Complex 1 is a 3D coordination polymer composed of binuclear Co2 units, while complex 2 is a layered structure with trinuclear Mn3 units. Selective gas adsorption and magnetic studies have been achieved in 1 and 2, respectively.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Coordination polymers with various intriguing structural motifs have been extensively studied for their versatile chemical and physical properties, as well as potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, solvent exchange, magnetism, and so on.(1) Research community has shown growing interest in the magnetic and sorption properties of coordination polymers during the past decade. The carboxylate functional group having different coordination modes has been extensively used for constructing polynuclear clusters and transmitting magnetic exchanges.(2) Magnetic exchange is also promoted by the imidazole between paramagnetic metal centers.(3) Therefore, if a ligand contains both carboxylate and imidazole donor moieties, it can potentially tune the magnetic exchange and lead to interesting magnetic properties.(4) Magnetic moment is generated by metal ions, whereas the bridging ligand allows the magnetic exchange coupling between magnetic centers.(5)
    Recently, porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have emerged as an important new class of materials because of their ability to selectively adsorb gases.(6) One of the most important features of PCPs is their ability to sense incoming guest molecules, which is predominantly governed by the window dimensions, presence of functional groups in the channels, and flexibility of these materials.(7) CO2 is a necessary intermediate product in most of the hydrogen production processes and it is also the main component of greenhouse gases. Hence, separation and storage of CO2 will become increasingly important in future.(8)
    Herein, we have designed a new bifurcated ligand incorporating benzimidazole and cyanide functional group at their end. The cyanide group gets hydrolyzed to its corresponding carboxylate under solvothermal conditions in presence of acid or base. The important feature of this ligand is possibility of rotation about the C–N single bond (Scheme 1) that can potentially lead to a number of useful structures with metal ions.(9) Two coordination polymers, {[Co2(DBIBA)3]·Cl•9H2O}n (1) and {[Mn3(DBIBA)6]}n (2) have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Complex 1 shows high selectivity for CO2 adsorption, while complex 2 shows antiferromagnetic behavior.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References

    Materials and Methods

    Reagent grade 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile and metal salts were acquired from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents, benzimidazole and K2CO3 were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. Solvents were purified prior to use following standard procedures.

    Physical Measurements

    Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400–4000 cm–1) using a Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer.1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded using a JEOL-ECX 500 FT (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument in CDCl3 with Me4Si as the internal standard. ESI mass spectra were recorded using a WATERS Q-TOF premier mass spectrometer. TGA were recorded using a Mettler Toledo (heating rate of 10◦C/min) TGA instrument. Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a Rigaku Rint 2000 X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Magnetic measurements were carried out in the Unitat de Mesures Magnetiques (Universitat de Barcelona) on polycrystalline samples (ca. 30 mg) with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer equipped with a 5 T magnet. Diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constants(10) and an experimental correction factor for the sample holder was applied. Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric BELSORP-MINI-II adsorption equipment. Prior to BET adsorption measurements, the complex 1 was immersed in dichloro methane (DCM) for 3 days at room temperature to replace guest molecules from the lattice by DCM and after that, the complex was heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to remove the solvent molecules.

    Synthesis of the Ligand

    Synthesis of the ligand was achieved in several steps as described below.

    5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl) Benzonitrile (DBIBN)

    This ligand was synthesized following a reported procedure.(11) A mixture of benzimidazole (3.4 g, 28.8 mmol), 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile (2 g, 14.4 mmol), and K2CO3(6 g, 43.2 mmol) in 10 mL of dry DMF was heated at 80 °C for 48 h with constant stirring under nitrogen atmosphere. After it was cooled to room temperature, the mixture was poured slowly in ice-cold water (100 mL) with constant stirring to obtain a white solid that was collected by filteration and air-dried. Yield: 3.0 g, (65%). Melting point:170 °C. IR(cm–1): 3395(m), 3077(m), 2236(w), 1599(s), 1501(s), 1483(w), 1467(s), 1406(m), 1364(w), 1291(s), 1248(m), 1229(s), 1202(s), 1138(w), 1054(w), 1013(w), 876(m), 853(w), 775(m), 763(m), 733(s), 686(m), 624(w), 498(w), 456(w), 425(w). 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 8.23(s, 2H, ArH), 8.00(m, 1H, ArH), 7.93(m, 4H, ArH), 7.59(m, 2H, ArH), 7.43(m, 4H, ArH). 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 144.33, 141.44, 139.32, 132.80, 125.65, 125.00, 124.10, 122.68, 121.48, 116.49, 109.88. Elemental analysis calcd for C21H13N5 (335.13): C, 75.26; H, 3.90; N, 20.89%. Found: C, 74.87; H, 3.80; N, 19.19%. ESI-MS: m/z (100%) 336.1186 [M + 1]+. The spectra related to this ligand are given in the Supporting Information as Figures S3–S6.

    Synthesis of {[Co2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·9H2O}n (1)

    A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.07 g, 0.24 mmol), DBIBN (0.04 g, 0.12 mmol), and conc. HCl (0.1 mL) in EtOH/H2O (3 mL, 2:1 v/v) were placed in a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. Needle-shaped reddish brown crystals of 1 were collected in 50% yield. The crystals were repeatedly washed with ethanol and air-dried. Anal. Calcd for C63H57N12O15ClCo2: C, 55.01; H, 4.17; N, 12.21%. Found: C, 54.24; H, 3.98; N, 11.91%. IR (cm–1): 3399(m), 3137(w), 3073(w), 3002(w), 1712(w), 1647(m), 1597(s), 1502(s), 1472(m), 1401(s), 1373(m), 1305(w), 1293(m), 1242(s), 1222(w), 1173(w), 1148(w), 1109(w), 1011(w), 908(w), 862(w), 794(w), 777(w), 764(w), 745(s), 720(w), 693(w), 626(w), 522(w), 426(m) (Figure S7, Supporting Information).

    Synthesis of {[Mn3(DBIBA)6]}n (2)

    A mixture of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.06 g, 0.24 mmol), DBIBN (0.04 g, 0.12 mmol), and Et3N (0.1 mL) in EtOH/H2O (3 mL, 2:1 v/v) were sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. After that the mixture was cooled to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. Block shaped colorless crystals of 2 were collected in 45% yield. The crystals were repeatedly washed with ethanol and air-dried. Anal. Calcd for C126H78N24O12Mn3: C, 66.23; H, 3.44; N, 14.71%. Found: C, 65.81; H, 3.14; N, 13.29%. IR (cm–1): 3754(w), 3395(w), 3051(m), 2376(w), 1592(s), 1494(s), 1411(s), 1297(m), 1223(s), 1011(w), 882(m), 742(s), 516(w), 430(m) (Figure S8, Supporting Information).

    Single-Crystal X-ray Studies

    Single-crystal X-ray data on complexes 1–2 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Data integration and reduction were processed(12) with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction factor was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS(13) and the space group was determined using XPREP.(14) The structure was solved by direct method using SHELXTL-97(15) and refined on F2 by full matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL-97(16) package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters. For compound 1, squeeze refinement has been performed using PLATON that shows nine water molecules per formula weight. The contribution of both the hydrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms have been incorporated in both the empirical formula and formula weight in Table 1. The high angle data could be obtained for compound 1 that is why in this case the data completeness was found to be 0.93. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table 1, while selective bond angles and bond distances are given in Table S1, Supporting Information.
    Table 1. Crystal and Structure Refinement Data for Compounds 1 and 2
     12

    formula wt.1375.502284.94

    b (Å)17.031(5)14.580(6)
    c (Å)13.922(4)15.041(4)
    α (deg)90.0071.922(3)

    γ (deg)120.0080.586(6)

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    The ligand 3,5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DBIBN) undergoes hydrolysis under solvothermal condition to give metal bounded 3,5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzoate (DBIBA). The sharp peak due to nitrile stretching at 2232 cm–1 in the IR spectrum of ligand is not observed in either 1 or 2. Instead, strong absorption bands in the region, 1350–1550 cm–1 are observed indicative of coordinated carboxylates(17) the broad bands at the region ∼3100–3350 cm–1 indicates(18) the presence of lattice water molecules in 1(Figures S7–S8, Supporting Information). Both the imidazole N and carboxylate O atoms bind the metal ions to form coordination polymers. Once the compounds are formed, they are found to be insoluble in common organic solvents as well as in water and are stable in air. A series of coordination polymers with 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid, similar to our ligand based on imidazole, have been reported by Sun and co-workers(19) and a series of coordination polymers by the in situ hydrolysis of 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile have been reported by our group.(20)

    X-ray Structural Studies

    Complex 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅1c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Co(II) ion with 1/3 occupancy, half ligand (DBIBA–), one chloride ion (shows hydrogen bonding, see Figure S1) with 1/6 occupancy, and one and a half lattice water molecule. The structure contains a binuclear Co(II) unit built through three bridging carboxylates, while the other three coordination sites of each metal ion are occupied by three benzimidazole N atoms forming a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure 1).
    In the dimeric unit, the two metal ions are triply carboxylate-bridged, which remain 4.104 Å apart. Further the dimeric units are connected to benzimidazole N atoms to form a chain along the crystallographic a axis (Figure 2). All the bond distances involving the metal ion are found(21) to be within normal statistical errors.
    When viewed along the c axis, 1D hexagonal channels of diameter ∼6.3 Å (considering the van der Waals radii) can be observed (Figure 3c). Topological analysis shows that 1 has 4,6-connected net having schlafli symbol {44·62}3{49·66}2 considering Co(II) ions as 6-connected nodes and DBIBA–ligand as 4-connected nodes (Figure 3).(22) The solvent accessible volume is 32.8% of the unit cell volume, calculated from the crystal structure using the PLATON program.(23)
    Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of two crystallographically independent Mn(II) ions, and three DBIBA– ligands. One of the Mn(II) ion is situated at the center of symmetry therefore has half occupancy. The structure forms a unit of three Mn(II) ions coordinated by bridging carboxylates (Figure 4). In this trinuclear cluster, each terminal metal center shows distorted octahedral MnN2O4 coordination geometry from four bridging carboxylate O (Mn–O = 2.082(6)-2.436(5) Å) and two N atoms of benzimidazole (Mn–N = 2.238(6)-2.297(6) Å). The middle metal atom shows distorted octahedral MnO6 coordination geometry from six bridging carboxylate O (Mn–O = 2.108(5)-2.314(6) Å). All the bond distances involving the metal ion are within statistical errors compared to literature(24) values.
    The metal bound N atoms of the benzimidazole moieties extend this structure along the crystallographic a axis to form a 2-dimentional layered structure (Figure 5). The linear trimeric manganese present in the structure is further extended by T-shaped π–π stacking interaction between 2D layers makes the overall structure 3D framework (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Topological analysis of 2 shows that the framework consists of 4-connected sql/Shubnikov net having schlafli symbol 4462 (Figure 6).
    Thermal stabilities of both the complexes were examined. Complex 1 and 2 shows high thermal stability. Complex 1 shows a weight loss of ∼12% (expected = 11.8%) in the temperature range of 80–180 °C that corresponds to loss of nine lattice water molecules. Decomposition of complex 1takes place only above 400 °C (see Figure S11). Complex 2 also shows a high thermal stability up to 450 °C. Complete decomposition is observed beyond 450 °C (see Figure S12).

    Magnetic Properties

    Complex 2 is a 2D coordination polymer built with carboxylate bridged trimeric Mn(II) units. Distance between central Mn(II) and either peripheral Mn(II) is 3.885 Å. (Figure 7). As carboxylate bridging can propagate(25) magnetic properties, this compound was subjected to variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements.
    The data for 2 were collected at an applied dc field of 0.3 T in the temperature range, 2–300 K and are shown in Figure 8as χT versus T plot. The χT product has a value of 14.0 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K, in agreement with the expected value for three noninteracting Mn(II) ions with g = 2.1 and S = 5/2. With lowering of temperature, the χT product decreases slightly, until a sharp decrease is observed below 100 K. The value reaches to 4.2 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, as expected for a ground state spin of S = 5/2. The coupling between metal centers is weakly antiferromagnetic, as expected for Mn(II) ions bridged by carboxylate ligands. The experimental susceptibility data can be modeled(26) using the Kambe or equivalent operator approach. The spin Hamiltonian of eq 1 can be analytically solved to find the eigen-values of each spin level, which can in-turn be used to write a Van Vleck equation (eq 1) to model the magnetic susceptibility data. The Ŝi terms of the Hamiltonian are the spin operators on each i metal, as labeled in the model shown in Figure 7. The equation obtained was used to fit the experimental data, resulting in the best fit shown in Figure 8 as a solid line. The best fitting parameters were J1 = −1.07 cm–1 and g = 2.1, with J2 kept fixed as J2 = 0. This is confirmed by the reduced magnetization data measured at 2 K, as shown in Figure 9. The magnetization follows(27) the Brillouin law for an S = 5/2 with g = 2.0, shown as a solid line in Figure 9, reaching a saturation at 5 T at a value of M/NμB = 5.(1)

    Gas Adsorption Studies

    Compound 1 being quite porous with 32.8% of void volume, was subjected to gas adsorption studies. The gas adsorption experiments were carried out using N2, H2, and CO2 under different experimental conditions. The compound was activated by immersing in DCM for 3 days followed by heating at 120 °C for 12 h. Framework remains intact after desolvation that is confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figures S9, Supporting Information). Gas adsorption studies were conducted at low pressure on this desolvated 1 with N2 at 77 K, CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K, and H2 at 77 K respectively (Figure 10). N2 and H2 did not diffuse into the pores of 1 even at 77 K and showed only surface adsorption (2.5 cm3 g–1 for N2 and 7.5 cm3 g–1 for H2 at P/Po = 1). Although the channel size (∼6 Å2) is large enough compared to the kinetic diameter of N2 and H2 (2.9 and 3.6 Å, respectively), this may be attributed to the 1D channel systems running along crystallographic c axis (Figure 3) in all the frameworks, and there are no additional effective channels along the a or b axis. Therefore, at very low temperatures (77 K), N2 or H2 molecules probably interact strongly with pore aperture and block other molecules to pass through, and resulting only in surface adsorption.
    However, CO2 adsorption experiment for 1 showed typical type I adsorption isotherm at 195, 273, and 298 K confirming the microporous nature of 1. The maximum CO2 uptakes at 1 atm and 195 K for desolvated 1 are 140.5 cm3 g–1 with Langmuir surface area 794 m2 g–1, calculated from CO2 profile using the Langmuir equation. At 273 and 298 K the adsorbate amount decreased to 52.1 cm3 g–1 and 44.2 cm3 g–1 respectively, which are moderately high and comparable to the recently reported values.(28) To study the selectivity of desolvated 1 at 195 K, we have performed adsorption isotherm measurements of N2, and Ar, which suggests an excellent selective nature for CO2 at the same temperature, 195 K (Figures S13, Supporting Information). Therefore, nature of channels and interior wall composed of linker and metal ions that can interact with linear CO2 molecules, could be the crucial factors for such high selectivity.

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Two new coordination polymers have been synthesized with DBIBN ligand under in situ cyanide hydrolysis. Compound 1 shows reversible and selective adsorption of CO2 at low pressure, while compound 2 shows weak antiferromagnetic behavior. Possible extension of this work is in progress with other transition and lanthanide metals in our laboratory.

      1a
      Applicability of the BET Method for Determining Surface Areas of Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Walton, Krista S.; Snurr, Randall Q.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (27), 8552-8556CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The surface area is one of the most important quantities for characterizing novel porous materials. The BET anal. is the std. method for detg. surface areas from nitrogen adsorption isotherms and was originally derived for multilayer gas adsorption onto flat surfaces. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a relatively new class of cryst., porous materials that exhibit very large BET surface areas. These materials are microporous and possess surfaces that are far from flat. In some MOFs, adsorption occurs through a pore-filling mechanism rather than by layer formation. Thus, it is unclear whether BET surface area nos. reported for these materials are truly meaningful. Given the std. practice of reporting BET surface areas for novel porous materials, a crit. test of the BET method is much needed. Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were used to predict adsorption isotherms for nitrogen in MOFs. The predicted isotherms were used as pseudoexperimental data to test the applicability of the BET theory for obtaining surface areas of microporous MOFs. BET surface areas calcd. from the simulated isotherms agree very well with the accessible surface areas calcd. directly from the crystal structures in a geometric fashion. The surface areas agree well with exptl. reports in the literature. These results provide a strong validation that the BET theory can be used to obtain surface areas of MOFs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (b) Wang, C. M.; Zheng, S. T.; Yang, G. Y. Inorg. Chem. 2007, 46, 616
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1b
      Novel Copper-Complex-Substituted Tungstogermanates
      Wang, Chun-Mei; Zheng, Shou-Tian; Yang, Guo-Yu
      Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (3), 616-618CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two Cu-complex-substituted tungstogermanates [Cu5(2,2'-bpy)6(H2O)][GeW8O31]·9H2O, 1, and {[Cu5(2,2'-bpy)5(H2O)][GeW9O34]}2·7H2O, 2 (2,2'-bpy = 2,2'-bipyridyl), were hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. X-ray structural analyses show that 1 is a rare tetralacunary Keggin anion of [B-β-GeW8O31]10- substituted by Cu complexes, while dimer 2 consists of two trilacunary [B-α-GeW9O34]10- Keggin units bridged by Cu complexes. Magnetic measurement for 2 shows antiferromagnetic interactions within the dinuclear Cu2+ cations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXjtVantA%253D%253D&md5=1b3ca3cdef803841f89c66c57b1ab6c0
      (c) Zhao, H. X.; Zhuang, G. L.; Wu, S. T.; Long, L. S.; Guo, H. Y.; Ye, Z. G.; Huang, R. B.; Zheng, L. S. Chem. Commun. 2009, 1644
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1c
      Experimental and theoretical demonstration of ferroelectric anisotropy in a one-dimensional copper(ii)-based coordination polymer
      Zhao, Hai-Xia; Zhuang, Gui-Lin; Wu, Shu-Ting; Long, La-Sheng; Guo, Hai-Yan; Ye, Zuo-Guang; Huang, Rong-Bin; Zheng, Lan-Sun
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2009), (13), 1644-1646CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The anisotropy of polarization in a 1-dimensional Cu(II)-based coordination polymer was studied exptl. and theor. for the 1st time, revealing that the origin of the ferroelectricity and its anisotropic nature are closely related to the coordination geometry of the metal ion and the packing mode of the coordination polymer.

      1d
      Three New Heterothiometallic Cluster Polymers with Fascinating Topologies
      Pan, Zhaorui; Xu, Jiao; Zheng, Hegen; Huang, Kexuan; Li, Yizhi; Guo, Zijian; Batten, Stuart R.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (13), 5772-5778CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Three new heterothiometallic cluster polymers with fascinating topologies were synthesized by the self-assembly of preformed heterothiometallic cluster monomers and appropriate ligands. Reaction of the monomeric cubic-shaped cluster [Et4N]3[MoOS3Cu3I4] with the D2h symmetry rigid bidentate 4,4'-bipy (4,4'-bipyridine) gave a two-dimensional (2D) layer compd. [Mo2O2S6Cu6I2(4,4'-bipy)3(H2O)]n (1); the assembly of pentanuclear cluster monomer [Et4N]4[WS4Cu4I6] with Cs-sym. bpe (1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane) afforded a 2-dimensional layer compd. [WS4Cu4I2(bpe)3(H2O)]n (2), and the assembly of heptanuclear cluster monomer [Et4N]4[WS4Cu6I8] with D3h symmetry trigonal planar ligand timtz (2,4,6-tri(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-1,3,5-triazine) afforded a three-dimensional (3D) compd. [WS4Cu6I4(timtz)8/3(H2O)12]n (3). X-ray crystallog. anal. reveals that 1 crystallizes in trigonal space group R3‾c with 2-dimensional 36-hxl net which is the 1st heterothiometallic superamol. structure based on a twin cubic-shaped cluster monomer and also the 1st example of 4,4'-bipy-connected compd. of this net. 2 Crystallizes in tetragonal space group P42 with distorted 2-dimensional 36-hxl net which is the 1st flexible-ligand-based compd. of this topol.; while 3 has a 3-dimensional net with the high symmetry of cubic space group I4‾3d, and has a novel α-C3N4 topol., which is the max. symmetry for this net topol. The gas sorption isotherm was measured for 3 to exhibit type-III sorption behavior.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXmvVemt74%253D&md5=49fbdb5665d18b54ad2f62b87545ccb2

      1e
      Design of bimetallic magnetic chains based on oxalate complexes: towards single chain magnets
      Coronado, Eugenio; Galan-Mascaros, Jose R.; Marti-Gastaldo, Carlos
      CrystEngComm (2009), 11 (10), 2143-2153CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      We describe the synthesis, structure and magnetic characterization of several oxalate-based bimetallic 1D systems. We will exemplify how by suitable choice of the mol. building blocks and strict control of their arrangement in the solid state, the magnetic properties of these low-dimensional materials can be tuned to finally obtain bimetallic oxalate chains behaving as single-chain magnets (SCM). First, we will focus on compds. [K(18-crown-6)][MII(bpy)Cr(ox)3] (1, 2; MII = Mn, Co; bpy = C10N2H8). The MnCr deriv. behaves as a 1D ferromagnet down to 2 K, the lowest investigated temp. The lack of magnetic ordering in this chain prompted us to prep. the more anisotropic MnCo deriv. with the aim of checking whether the single-chain magnetic behavior was obsd. However, this compd. exhibits long-range ferromagnetic ordering at Tc = 5.5 K due to the poor chain insulation. Next, in order to slightly change the supramol. interactions between neighboring chains we substituted the bpy ligand with dpy, in view of its ability to establish H bonds, yielding the bimetallic compds. [K(18-crown-6)][Co(bpy)MIII(ox)3] (3, 4; MIII = Cr, Fe; dpy = C10N3H9). These compds. exhibit long-range magnetic ordering at 4.6 and 11 K, resp., and a frequency dependence of the ac susceptibility at lower temps. However, such behavior cannot be attributed to a SCM relaxation, but to the movement of domain walls in the ordered state. Finally, by introducing an addnl. cation, which increases the interlayer sepn., we obtained the compd. [K(18-crown-6)]1/2[(18-crown-6)(FC6H4NH3)]1/2[Co(H2O)2Cr(ox)3] (5) exhibiting a SCM-like behavior.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVSksr%252FL&md5=dcb5fe3569b17db602144916c4da7bf9
      (f) Ahmad, M.; Sharma, M. K.; Das, R.; Poddar, P.; Bharadwaj, P. K. Cryst. Growth Des. 2012, 12, 1571
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1f
      Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Magnetic Properties of Metal-Organic Hybrid Materials of Co(II) Using Flexible and Rigid Nitrogen-Based Ditopic Ligands as Spacers
      Ahmad, Musheer; Sharma, Manish K.; Das, Raja; Poddar, Pankaj; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
      Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (3), 1571-1578CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      A carboxylate-based flexible ligand, 5-(4-carboxybenzyloxy)isophthalic acid (p-cbiaH3), readily reacts with Co(II) salts in the presence of different pyridine-based coligands such as 1,4-bis(4-pyridinylmethyl)piperazine (bpmp) or 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe) under hydrothermal conditions to afford two different three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers, {[Co4(OH)2(p-cbia)2(bpmp)(H2O)3]·2H2O}n (1) and {[Co4(OH)2(p-cbia)2(dpe)(H2O)4]·2H2O}n (2). Both compds. were characterized by x-ray crystallog., IR spectroscopy, TG, and elemental anal. Single-crystal x-ray diffraction studies reveal that both compds. consist of a tetranuclear core [Co4(μ3-OH)2]6+. Compd. 1 is a unprecedented 3-dimensional noninterpenetrated (3,4,9)-connected pkb3 net. However, compd. 2 is a 2-fold interpenetrated (3,8)-connected tfz-d net. Variable temp. static and dynamic magnetic measurements show that both compds. exhibit ferromagnetic behavior assocd. with mixed hydroxyl/carboxylate-bridged tetranuclear Co(II) clusters as subunits.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (g) Sharma, M. K.; Senkovska, I.; Kaskel, S.; Bharadwaj, P. K. Inorg. Chem. 2011, 50, 539
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1g
      Three-Dimensional Porous Cd(II) Coordination Polymer with Large One-Dimensional Hexagonal Channels: High Pressure CH4 and H2 Adsorption Studies
      Sharma, Manish K.; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 50 (2), 539-544CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A new porous and hydrothermally stable three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer {[Cd(bpydb)]·6H2O}n (1) was synthesized under solvothermal condition from a new rigid ligand 4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)dibenzoic acid (H2bpydb) and Cd(NO3)2·6H2O. Single crystal x-ray anal. shows that 1 has a 5-connected 4466vma net with one-dimensional (1D) hexagonal channels filled with water mols. Integrity of the framework is maintained upon removal of the water mols. by heating to result in a porous framework. Low pressure N2 and high pressure H2 and CH4 sorption studies along with water adsorption studies were performed on this framework.

      1h
      Hydrothermal Synthesis, Structures, and Physical Properties of Four New Flexible Multicarboxylate Ligands-Based Compounds
      Pan, Zhaorui; Zheng, Hegen; Wang, Tianwei; Song, You; Li, Yizhi; Guo, Zijian; Batten, Stuart R.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2008), 47 (20), 9528-9536CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Four new compds. of partially or wholly deprotonated 5,5'-(1,4-phenylenebis(methylene))bis(oxy)diisophthalic acid (H4L1) and 5,5'-(1,3-phenylenebis(methylene))bis(oxy)diisophthalic acid (H4L2), {[Co(L1)0.5]·(H2O)2}n (1), {[Mn(L1)0.5]·(H2O)2}n (2), {[Cu(H2L1)](μ2-bipy)}n (bipy = 4,4'-bipyridyl) (3), and {[Zn2(L2)].H2O}n (4) were synthesized in the presence or absence of auxiliary bipy ligand. Their structures were detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction anal. and further characterized by elemental anal., IR spectra, and TGA. Compds. 1 and 2 are isostructural and possess three-dimensional (3D) networks. In compd. 3, multicarboxylate ligands and bipy ligands link Cu centers to generate a two-dimensional (2D) sheet structure which is further connected by intermol. hydrogen bonds to form a 3-dimensional supramol. structure. In compd. 4, the Zn centers are connected by L24- anions to generate a 3-dimensional framework. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that compds. 1 and 2 exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling between adjacent Co(II) ions and Mn(II) ions. The photoluminescent properties of the free H4L1 and H4L2 ligands and compd. 4 were studied in the solid state at room temp. Both ligands and compd. 4 exhibit strong violet emissions. Compared with the fluorescent emission of the ligand, the emission of 4 is red shifted and enhanced.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtFGntr3J&md5=78d3e89f95eab133b052beb754125dbf
      (i) Liu, H. K.; Huang, X. H.; Lu, T. H.; Wang, X. J.; Sun, W. Y.; Kang, B. S. Dalton Trans. 2008, 3178
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1i
      Discrete and infinite 1D, 2D/3D cage frameworks with inclusion of anionic species and anion-exchange reactions of Ag3L2 type receptor with tetrahedral and octahedral anions
      Liu, Hong-Ke; Huang, Xiaohua; Lu, Tianhong; Wang, Xiujian; Sun, Wei-Yin; Kang, Bei-Sheng
      Dalton Transactions (2008), (24), 3178-3188CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      [PF6⊂Ag3(titmb)2](PF6)2 (8) and [SbF6⊂Ag3(titmb)2](SbF6)2·H2O·1.5CH3OH (9) were obtained by reaction of titmb (1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene) and Ag+ salts with different anions (PF6- and SbF6-), and crystal structures reveal that they are both M3L2 cage complexes with short Ag···F interactions between the silver atoms and the fluorine atoms of the anions. In complex 8, a novel cage dimer is formed by weak Ag···F contacts; an unique cage tetramer formed via Ag···π interactions (Ag···η5-imidazole) between dimers and an infinite 1-dimensional cage chain is presented. However, each of the external non-disordered SbF6- anions connect with six cage 9s via Ag···F contacts, and each cage 9 in turn connects with three SbF6- anions to form a 2-dimensional network cage layer; and the layers are connected by π-π interactions to form a 3-dimensional network. The anion-exchange reactions of four Ag3L2 type complexes [BF4⊂Ag3(titmb)2](BF4)2 (6), [ClO4⊂Ag3(titmb)2](ClO4)2 (7b), [PF6⊂Ag3(titmb)2](PF6)2 (8) and [SbF6⊂Ag3(titmb)2](SbF6)2·1.5CH3OH (9) with tetrahedral and octahedral anions (ClO4-, BF4-, PF6- and SbF6-) are also reported. The anion-exchange expts. demonstrate that the anion selective order is SbF6- > PF6- > BF4-, ClO4-, and this anion receptor is preferred to trap octahedral and tetrahedral anions rather than linear or triangle anions; SbF6- is the biggest and most preferable one, so far. The dimensions of cage complexes with or without internal anions, anion-exchange reactions, cage assembly and anion inclusions, silver(I) coordination environments, Ag-F and Ag-π interactions of Ag3L2 complexes 1-9 are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXmvFGktbk%253D&md5=65fefaee8ab45e646e609e1c74da4c4f
      (j) Ding, D. G.; Wu, B. L.; Fan, Y. T.; Hou, H. W. Cryst. Growth Des. 2009, 9, 508

      1j
      Four Novel Metal Diphosphonate Compounds Based on 2-(1-Triazole)-1-Hydroxyl-1,1'-Ethylidenediphosphonic Acid: Syntheses, Topological Structures, and Magnetic Properties
      Ding, De-Gang; Wu, Ben-Lai; Fan, Yao-Ting; Hou, Hong-Wei
      Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (1), 508-516CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Hydrothermal reactions of Mn(II), Cu(II), Co(II), and Ni(II) salts with 2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1'-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (tahedpH4) lead to four novel metal phosphonates, namely, Mn2(tahedp)(H2O)2 (1), Cu2(tahedp)(H2O) (2), Co(tahedpH2) (3) and Ni2(tahedpH2)2·(NH2CH2CH2NH2) (4). In compd. 1, dimeric units {Mn12O2} are linked together by the O3-P1-O1 groups forming an inorg. chain. The adjacent chains are further connected by {Mn2O4N} pentahedra to form an undulating inorg. layer. The inorg. layers are bridged by the triazole groups resulting in a three-dimensional framework structure. The structure of 1 can be described as an unprecedented trinodal (4.66.83)2(42.62.82)(5.62)2 topol. network. Compd. 2 shows a pillared layered structure in which the {Cu12O2} dimers are linked together by the O3-P1-O1 groups forming a double chain. The double chains and the {-Cu2-O5-P2-O4-}2 eight-membered rings are further linked through the coordination of O2 and O6 atoms into a layer. The neighboring layers are connected together by the triazole rings, resulting in a pillared layered structure. Topol. anal. of compd. 2 reveals that it is a unique 3, 4, and 5-connected net with (42.6)2(42.84)(43.6.86)2 topol. Compd. 3 exhibits a layered structure made up of Co2(tahedpH2)2 dimer units. Compd. 4 exhibits a layered architecture that is built from {NiO5N} octahedra interconnected by phosphonate groups and triazole rings. Magnetic measurements reveal that antiferromagnetic interactions are mediated between magnetic centers in all four compds.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtl2jsbjK&md5=2f9a8567d866c4097c9987866add2b37

      (a) Masciocchi, N.; Galli, S.; Sironi, A.; Cariati, E.; Galindo, M. A.; Barea, E.; Romero, M. A.; Salas, J. M.; Navarro, J. A. R.; Santoyo-Gonzalez, F. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 7612

      2a
      Tuning the Structural and Magnetic Properties of Thermally Robust Coordination Polymers
      Masciocchi, Norberto; Galli, Simona; Sironi, Angelo; Cariati, Elena; Galindo, Miguel A.; Barea, Elisa; Romero, M. Angustias; Salas, Juan M.; Navarro, Jorge A. R.; Santoyo-Gonzalez, Francisco
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (19), 7612-7620CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Thermally robust materials of the M(5-X-pyrimidin-2-olate)2 type [M = Co, X = Cl (1Cl), X = Br (1Br), X = I (1I); M = Zn, X = Cl (2Cl), X = Br (2Br), X = I (2I)] were synthesized. Their x-ray powder diffraction structural characterization revealed that they crystallize as I‾42d diamondoid frameworks, isomorphous to those of the pristine [M(pyrimidin-2-olate)2]n analogs (1H, M = Co; 2H, M = Zn). The magnetic measurements of the 1X series at magnetic fields of 100, 300, and 5000 Oe reveal a weak ferromagnetic ordering taking place below the Neel temp. (TN ∼ 20 K), arising from spin canting phenomena of the antiferromagnetically coupled cobalt centers. Also, magnetic hysteresis studies carried out on the 1X series at 2 K reveal a strong dependence of both the coercive field Hcoer (2500, 1000, 775, and 500 Oe for 1Br, 1Cl, 1I, and 1H, resp.) and the remnant magnetization Mrem (0.0501 μB for 1Br and 1Cl, 0.0457 μB for 1I, and 0.0358 μB for 1H) on the 5-substituent of the pyrimidin-2-olates. The mol. alloys [Co(5-Y-pyrimidin-2-olate)2] (Y = Cl/Br, 1Cl/Br) and [Co(5-Y'-pyrimidin-2-olate)2] (Y' = Br/I, 1Br/I) also were prepd. and characterized, proving that they have intermediate properties. These materials combine interesting functional properties, such as chem. inertness, magnetism, photoluminescence, and (although weak) SHG activity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XotVGntbo%253D&md5=0646819cded062401a13cfd53e5cd632
      (b) Galet, A.; Gaspar, A. B.; Munoz, M. C.; Bukin, G. V.; Levchenko, G.; Real, J. A. Adv. Mater. 2005, 17, 2949
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2b
      Tunable bistability in a three-dimensional spin-crossover sensory- and memory-functional material
      Galet, Ana; Gaspar, Ana Belen; Munoz, M. Carmen; Bukin, Gennadiy V.; Levchenko, Georgii; Real, Jose Antonio
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2005), 17 (24), 2949-2953CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Spin-crossover (SCO) complexes based on three-dimensional coordination polymers exhibit unprecedented pressure-tunable thermal and piezochromic bistability at room temp. The thermal- and piezohysteresis loops of the material can be tuned, providing a step towards reliable pressure-based memory systems or displays.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xlt1WmsA%253D%253D&md5=3dd4ee05e2cd19579da3b9066343493d

      2c
      Coexistence of ferromagnetism and metallic conductivity in a molecule-based layered compound
      Coronado, Eugenio; Galan-Mascaros, Jose R.; Gomez-Garcia, Carlos J.; Laukhin, Vladimir
      Nature (London) (2000), 408 (6811), 447-449CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Crystal engineering-the planning and construction of cryst. supramol. architectures from modular building blocks-permits the rational design of functional mol. materials that exhibit technol. useful behavior such as cond. and supercond., ferromagnetism and nonlinear optical properties. Because the presence of two cooperative properties in the same crystal lattice might result in new phys. phenomena and novel applications, a particularly attractive goal is the design of mol. materials with two properties that are difficult or impossible to combine in a conventional inorg. solid with a continuous lattice. A promising strategy for creating this type of "bi-functionality" targets hybrid org./inorg. crystals comprising two functional sub-lattices exhibiting distinct properties. In this way, the org. π-electron donor bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF) and its derivs., which form the basis of most known mol. conductors and superconductors, have been combined with mol. magnetic anions, yielding predominantly materials with conventional semiconducting or conducting properties, but also systems that are both superconducting and paramagnetic. But interesting bulk magnetic properties fail to develop, owing to the discrete nature of the inorg. anions. Another strategy for achieving cooperative magnetism involves insertion of functional bulky cations into a polymeric magnetic anion, such as the bimetallic oxalato complex [MnIICrIII(C2O4)3]-, but only insol. powders have been obtained in most cases. Here we report the synthesis of single crystals formed by infinite sheets of this magnetic coordination polymer interleaved with layers of conducting BEDT-TTF cations, and show that this mol.-based compd. displays ferromagnetism and metallic cond.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXos1Srsbg%253D&md5=95dde17fdfaa93e00969cd2e9b03d555
      (d) Zheng, Y.-Z.; Xue, W.; Zhang, W.-X.; Tong, M.-L.; Chen, X.-M.; Grandjean, F.; Long, G. J.; Ng, S.-W.; Panissod, P.; Drillon, M. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 2028
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2d
      Spin-Frustrated Complex, [FeIIFeIII(trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate)1.5]∞: Interplay between Single-Chain Magnetic Behavior and Magnetic Ordering
      Zheng, Yan-Zhen; Xue, Wei; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Tong, Ming-Liang; Chen, Xiao-Ming; Grandjean, Fernande; Long, Gary J.; Ng, Seik-Weng; Panissod, Pierre; Drillon, Marc
      Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (5), 2028-2042CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A three-dimensional mixed-valent iron(II,III) trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate, 1,4-chdc, coordination polymer, [FeIIFeIII(μ4-O)(1,4-chdc)1.5]∞ (1) was synthesized hydrothermally by mixing iron powder and 1,4-chdcH2 and studied by x-ray diffraction, d.c. and a.c. magnetic susceptibility, and iron-57 Moessbauer spectroscopy over a wide range of temps. Single-crystal x-ray diffraction studies of 1 at 90(2), 293(2), and 473(2) K reveal a tetrahedral [FeII2(μ4-O)FeIII2(μ4-O)]6+ mixed-spin-chain structure with no change in the P‾1 space group but with subtle changes in the Fe-O and Fe···Fe distances with increasing temp. These changes are assocd. with the electron delocalization obsd. by Mossbauer spectroscopy >225 K. Magnetic studies reveal three different magnetic regimes in 1 between 2 and 320 K. Above 36 K 1 is a 1-dimensional ferrimagnetic-like complex with frustration arising from competing exchange interactions between the iron(II) and iron(III) ions in the chains. Between 36 and 25 K the interchain interactions are nonnegligible and 1 undergoes three-dimensional ordering at 32.16 K but with some residual fluctuations. Below 25 K the residual fluctuations slow and eventually freeze <15 K; the small net moment of 0.22 μB per mol. of 1 obsd. <15 K may be attributed to a noncollinear or canted spin structure of the spins of the four iron ions in the [FeII2(μ4-O)FeIII2(μ4-O)]6+ chains. Below 32 K the Mossbauer spectra of 1 exhibit sharp sextets for both the iron(III) and iron(II) ionSiO2s and are consistent with either a static long-range or a short-range magnetic ground state or a slow relaxation between two canted magnetic states that are indistinguishable at the obsd. spectral resoln. The 85 and 155 K spectra reveal no electron delocalization and correspond solely to fixed valence iron(II) and iron(III). Between 225 and 310 K the spectra reveal the onset of electron delocalization such that, at 295 to 310 K, 25, 25, and 50% of the iron in 1 is present as iron(II), iron(III), and iron(II/III) ions, resp. The absence of any spectral line broadening assocd. with this electron delocalization and the coexistence of four doublets between 225 and 310 K indicate that the delocalization occurs through electron tunneling via vibronic coupling. The sudden increase in the tunneling rate beginning ⪆260 K and the presence of a cusp in the magnetic susceptibility centered at ∼275 K strongly suggest the existence of a charge order/disorder transition whose nature and order are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlegsLk%253D&md5=f4a3d1cde65557fd939cb687e8c7bc42
      (e) Cheng, X.-N.; Zhang, W.-X.; Zheng, Y.-Z.; Chen, X.-M. Chem. Commun. 2006, 34, 3603
      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      (f) Luo, F.; Che, Y.-X.; Zheng, J.-M. Cryst. Growth Des. 2009, 9, 1066
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2f
      Trinuclear Cobalt Based Porous Coordination Polymers Showing Unique Topological and Magnetic Variety upon Different Dicarboxylate-like Ligands
      Luo, Feng; Che, Yun-xia; Zheng, Ji-min
      Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (2), 1066-1071CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      One-pot solvothermal self-assembly is employed to prep. Co3 based porous coordination polymers, viz. (1), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(i.p.)4]·H2O; (2), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(bdc)4]·(DMF)2; (3), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(bpdc)4]·(CH3OH)2(DMF)1.5, where i.p., bdc, bpdc, and DMF are 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate, and N,N'-DMF, resp. Via different org. connectors such as i.p., bdc, and bpdc, such Co3 mol. building blocks (MBB), [Co3(CO2)8]2-, are assocd. together to give a tunable 8-connected topol. framework, viz. 42464 for 1, 36414576 for 2, and 36418536 for 3. Upon the geometry and the length of org. connectors, their corresponding porosity occupied by c counterions plus solvent mols. also can be tunable, for example, with the consideration of [H2NMe2]+ counterions, the solvent-accessible vol. is 460.2 Å3 for 1, equal to 23.9% of the cell vol., 3320.4 Å3 for 2, equal to 56.3% of the cell vol., 4107.2 Å3 for 3, equal to 50% of the cell vol. Notably, besides these outstanding features of tunable 8-connected topol. and porosity, their magnetic properties such as ferromagnetic behavior without magnetic ordering for 1, spin-canting and metamagnetic behavior with magnetic ordering for 2, as well as spin-canting, metamagnetic, and spin-glass behavior with magnetic ordering for 3 also can be tunable.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsVGnsLrM&md5=c3077f5101e9d684b77ac34721e589f3

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2g
      Metal-Organic Frameworks from Homometallic Chains of Nickel(II) and 1,4-Cyclohexanedicarboxylate Connectors: Ferrimagnet-Ferromagnet Transformation
      Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Kumagai, Hitoshi; Akita-Tanaka, Motoko; Inoue, Katsuya; Takagi, Seishi
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (4), 1627-1637CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The hydrothermal reactions of Ni(NO3)2 with a mixt. of the geometric cis and trans isomers of 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (1,4-chdc or C6H10(COOH)2) and a base yield three structurally different complexes, [Ni3(μ3-OH)2(μ4-cis-1,4-chdc)2(H2O)4]·2H2O (1), [Ni3(μ3-OH)2(μ4-trans-1,4-chdc)2(H2O)4]·4H2O (2), and [Ni(H2O)4(μ2-trans-1,4-chdc)] (3), depending on the reaction conditions. The single-crystal x-ray structure analyses of 1 and 2 reveal segregation of the isomers and formation of frameworks based on infinite Ni3(OH)2(H2O)4 chains, acting as secondary building units, connected by either cis- or trans-chdc for 1 and 2, resp. The frameworks sustain channels that house two or four H2O mols., resp., according to the size and shape of the channels that depend on the particular isomer. The structure of 3 consists of chains of square-planar Ni(H2O)4 bridged by trans-chdc. Magnetic data as a function of temp. and field of the virgin samples for 1 indicate long-range ordering (LRO) to a ferrimagnetic ground state at 2.1 K that is reversibly transformed into a ferromagnet <4.4 K upon partial dehydration and rehydration. Powder x-ray diffraction of 1, in its virgin state, after dehydration and after rehydration, confirms the stability of the framework. The magnetic data for 2 tend toward a LRO state to possibly a ferrimagnet <2 K. The temp. dependence of the susceptibility of the two compds. is accounted for by the presence of both ferro- and antiferromagnetic exchanges within each chain via Ni-O-Ni and Ni-O-C-O-Ni pathways and weak coupling between neighboring chains via the 1,4-chdc unit. 3 Is a uniform s = 1 antiferromagnetic chain (J/kB = 2.27(1) K).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XksFSitg%253D%253D&md5=4395033d71fe14b4c1140c54342aa0cd
      (h) Wang, S.; Bai, J.; Xing, H.; Li, Y.; Song, Y.; Pan, Y.; Scheer, M.; You, X. Cryst. Growth Des. 2007, 7, 747
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2h
      Novel Alternating Ferro-Ferromagnetic Two-Dimensional (4,4) and Photoluminescent Three-Dimensional Interpenetrating PtS-Type Coordination Networks Constructed from a New Flexible Tripodal Ligand as a Four-Connected Node
      Wang, Suna; Bai, Junfeng; Xing, Hang; Li, Yizhi; Song, You; Pan, Yi; Scheer, Manfred; You, Xiaozeng
      Crystal Growth & Design (2007), 7 (4), 747-754CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Two novel two-dimensional (2D) and one three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers, [Ni(HTTG)(H2O)2]n (1), [Co(HTTG)(H2O)2]n (2), and [Cd(HTTG)]n (3), were hydrothermally synthesized by self-assembly of an unexplored tripodal ligand H3TTG (N,N',N''-1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyltris-glycine) and corresponding metal salts. X-ray diffraction anal. reveals that the three polymers exhibit novel frameworks due to diverse coordination conformations and different acid forms of the flexible tricarboxylate ligands. The isostructural complexes 1 and 2 possess 2-dimensional frameworks with M(H2O)2(CO2)2 chains bridged by the ligands, and the resulting 3-dimensional networks were extended through R22(8) H bonds between the non-deprotonated carboxylate groups and the triazine rings as well as π···π interactions between the triazine rings. Complex 3 shows a 3-dimensional interpenetrating compact network with inorg. Cd2O2 chains interconnected by the flexible org. ligands. Topol. anal. indicates that in all three complexes the tripodal ligand acts as a four-connected square-planar node, linking four-connected square-planar or tetrahedral-connected metal centers to form interesting two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) (in 1 and 2) and three-dimensional (3D) 2-fold interpenetrating PtS topologies (in 3), resp. Both 1 and 2 exhibit ferromagnetic interactions within the chains bridged by the syn-anti carboxylate groups and the H2O mols. alternately, and complex 3 displays strong photoluminescent properties at 413 nm due to the coordination of the ligands with the metal centers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      3b
      The silica-like extended polymorphism of cobalt(II) imidazolate three-dimensional frameworks: X-ray single-crystal structures and magnetic properties
      Tian, Yun-qi; Cai, Chen-xin; Ren, Xiao-ming; Duan, Chun-ying; Xu, Yan; Gao, Song; You, Xiao-zeng
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2003), 9 (22), 5673-5685CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Five polymorphous frameworks of cobalt(II) imidazolates, {[Co(im)2]·1/2pyridine}∞ (1), {[Co(im)2]·1/2cyclohexanol}∞ (2), [Co(im)2]∞ (3, space group I41), [Co(im)2]∞ (4, space group I41cd) and {[Co(im)2]·2/5MB}∞ (5, MB = 3-methyl-1-butanol), were prepd. by solvothermal syntheses. Of these, compd. 3 has already been synthesized in a gas-phase reaction by Seel et al. in 1969 and structurally characterized by Sturm et al. in 1975. The new synthetic strategy affords four polymorphous frameworks of cobalt(II) imidazolates (1, 2, 4, 5) of cryst. substances, of which the compd. 4 (a = b = 23.450(3), c = 12.460(3) Å, tetragonal, space group I41cd, Z = 16) is an isomorphous compd. of [Zn(Im)2]∞, which was also synthesized in a gas-phase reaction in 1980. The frameworks of compds. 1 and 2 are porous and isostructural; they have the same framework topol. that represents a novel uninodal (6,4)-net: 1: a = 18.513(4), b = 24.368(5), c = 9.2940(19) Å, orthorhombic, space group Fdd2, Z = 16; 2: a = 17.635(4), b = 27.706(6), c = 9.0810(18) Å, orthorhombic, space group Fdd2, Z = 16. The framework of compd. 5 exhibits a topol. of zeolitic structure with the unit-cell parameters: a = 24.3406(8), b = 9.4526(3), c = 24.8470(8) Å, β = 91.977(1)°, monoclinic, space group P21/n, Z = 4. The crystal structure of {[Co(i.m.)2]·1/8H2O}∞ (2') and {[Zn(i.m.)2]·H2O}∞ (3') were also detd. All polymorphous frameworks of cobalt(II) imidazolates reflect the structural features of silica (SiO2) and also exhibit different magnetic behaviors, although the imidazolates transmit the antiferromagnetic coupling between the cobalt(II) ions in all cases. However, the uncompensated antiferromagnetic couplings arise from spin-canting are sensitive to the structures: compd. 1 is an antiferromagnet with TN = 13.11 K; compds. 2-4 are weak ferromagnets (canted antiferromagnets): 2 shows a very weak ferromagnetism <15 K, 3 exhibits a relatively strong ferromagnetism <11.5 K and a coercive field (HC) of 1800 Oe at 1.8 K, and 4 displays the strongest ferromagnetism of the three cobalt imidazolates and demonstrates a TC of 15.5 K with a coercive field, HC, of 7300 Oe at 1.8 K. However, compd. 5 seems to be a hidden canted antiferromagnet with a magnetic ordering temp. of 10.6 K.

      [Co5(im)10·2MB]∞: A metal-organic open-framework with zeolite-like topology
      Tian, Yun-Qi; Cai, Chen-Xin; Ji, Yong; You, Xiao-Zeng; Peng, Shie-Ming; Lee, Gene-Hsiang
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (8), 1384-1386CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      A highly robust metal-org. zeotype was created by expansion of the zeolite topol. The novel nanoporous material [Co5(Im)10·2MB]∞ (I; HIM = imidazole, MB = 3-methyl-1-butanol) structure exhibits not only a zeolite-like topol., but also the chem. functionalizable properties of zeolites. I is monoclinic, space group P21/n, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0688, wR2 = 0.230. [Co5(Im)10·0.5EtOH]∞ is monoclinic, space group P21/n, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0561, wR2 = 0.1149.

      3d
      Supramolecular Spin-Crossover Iron Complexes Based on Imidazole-Imidazolate Hydrogen Bonds
      Sunatsuki, Yukinari; Ohta, Hiromi; Kojima, Masaaki; Ikuta, Yuichi; Goto, Yoshiyuki; Matsumoto, Naohide; Iijima, Seiichiro; Akashi, Haruo; Kaizaki, Sumio; Dahan, Francoise; Tuchagues, Jean-Pierre
      Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (14), 4154-4171CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The [FeII(H3L)](BF4)2·3H2O (1) complex was synthesized, where H3L (tris{[2-{(imidazole-4-yl)methylidene}amino]ethyl}amine) is a tripodal ligand obtained by condensation of tris(2-aminoethyl)amine and 4-formylimidazole (fim) in a 1:3 molar ratio. Starting from 1, complexes, [FeII(H1.5L)](BF4)0.5 (2, which is [FeII(H3L)][FeII(L)]BF4), [Fe(H1.5L)]BF4 (3, which is [FeII(H3L)][FeIII(L)](BF4)2), [FeIII(H3L)](BF4)3·fim·H2O (4), and [FeIII(L)]·2.5H2O (5), were synthesized and characterized. The single-crystal x-ray structure of each complex was detd. The FeII compd., 2, and a mixed valence FeII-FeIII compd., 3, involve formally hemi-deprotonated ligands, H1.5L. The structure of 3 consists of a homochiral two-dimensional assembled sheet, arising from the intermol. H bonds between [FeII(H3L)]2+ and [FeIII(L)]0. All but 5 exhibit spin crossover between low-spin (LS) and high-spin (HS) states. This is a rare case where both FeII and FeIII complexes contg. the same ligand exhibit spin-crossover behavior. Magnetic susceptibility and Mossbauer studies showed that 3 has three accessible electronic states: LS FeII-LS FeIII, HS FeII-LS FeIII, and HS FeII-HS FeIII. Compds. 1-3 show the light-induced excited spin-state trapping effect (LIESST) at the FeII sites upon irradn. with green light. The soln. magnetic properties, electronic spectra, and electrochem. properties of 1, 4, and 5 were also studied.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXkvFSqtb4%253D&md5=66cca931095c1cb1d133b2c896c4bd50
      (e) Ding, B.-B.; Weng, Y.-Q.; Mao, Z.-W.; Lam, C.-K.; Chen, X.-M.; Ye, B.-H. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 8836

      3e
      Pillared-Layer Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed by Robust Hydrogen Bonds. Synthesis, Characterization, and Magnetic and Adsorption Properties of 2,2'-Biimidazole and Carboxylate Complexes
      Ding, Bing-Bing; Weng, Yan-Qin; Mao, Zong-Wan; Lam, Chi-Keung; Chen, Xiao-Ming; Ye, Bao-Hui
      Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (24), 8836-8845CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two new isostructural complexes, [M(H2biim)3][M(btc)(Hbiim)]·2H2O (M = Co, (1); M = Ni, (2); btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate; H2biim = 2,2'-biimidazole) were synthesized and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. They present a unique structure consisting of two distinct units: monomeric [M(H2biim)3]2+ and the two-dimensional (2D) anionic polymer [M(Hbiim)(btc)]2-. In the anionic moiety, the Hbiim- monoanion is simultaneously coordinated to one metal atom in a bidentate mode and further to another metal atom in a monodentate mode. The imidazolate groups bridge the two adjacent metal ions into a helical chain which is further arranged in left- and right-handed manners. These chains are bridged by btc ligands into a 2-dimensional brick wall structure. The most interesting aspect is that the [M(H2biim)3]2+ cations act as pillars and link the anionic layers via robust heteromeric hydrogen-bonded synthons R22(9) and R21(7) formed by the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups and the H2biim ligands, resulting in a microporous metal-org. framework with 1-dimensional (1D) channels (∼11.85 Å × 11.85 Å for 1 and 11.43 Å × 11.43 Å for 2). Magnetic properties of these two complexes also were studied at 2-300 K, and their magnetic susceptibilities obey the Curie-Weiss law at 20-300 K (for 1) and 2-300 K (for 2), resp., showing antiferromagnetic coupling through imidazolate bridging. Taking into consideration the Heisenberg infinite chain model as well as the possibility of chain-to-chain and chain-to-cation interactions, the antiferromagnetic exchange of 2 is analyzed via a correction for the mol. field, giving the values of gcat = 2.296, gNi = 2.564, J = -13.30 cm-1, and zJ' = -0.017 cm-1. The microporous frameworks are stable at ca. 350°. They do not collapse after removal of the guest water mols. in the channels, and they adsorb methanol mols. selectively.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFSjt73N&md5=d1bc14298294f03086d87b4977f77011

      (a) Zhang, X.-M.; Hao, Z.-M.; Zhang, W.-X.; Chen, X.-M. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2007, 46, 3456

      4a
      Dehydration-induced conversion from a single-chain magnet into a metamagnet in a homometallic nanoporous metal-organic framework
      Zhang, Xian-Ming; Hao, Zheng-Ming; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (19), 3456-3459CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      On dehydration, a 3D homometallic porous org.-inorg. framework constructed from {Co3(OH)2} chains undergoes a transition from being a single-chain magnet into a metamagnet. Apart from the loss of solvent water mols., the dehydration leaves the framework structure largely unchanged.

      4b
      Two Three-Dimensional Metal-Organic Frameworks Containing One-Dimensional Hydroxyl/Carboxylate Mixed Bridged Metal Chains: Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Magnetic Properties
      Li, Xiao-Ju; Wang, Xin-Yi; Gao, Song; Cao, Rong
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (4), 1508-1516CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two novel three-dimensional complexes formulated as [M3(bime)(μ3-OH)2(HO-BDC)2]n (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2) [bime = 1,2-bis(imidazol-1'-yl)ethane, HO-H2BDC = 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid] have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized. Both 1 and 2 exhibit similar structural frameworks resulting from one-dimensional metal/oxygen chains extended by HO-BDC but the bridging modes of HO-BDC and the coordination environments of the metal centers are different. Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the orthorhombic system, space group Pbcn, a = 18.458(2) [18.2119(12) for 2] Å, b = 12.0616(14) [11.6847(7) for 2] Å, c = 11.4859(14) [12.0688(6) for 2] Å, and Z = 4(4). Magnetic studies show that 1 displays a slow magnetic relaxation, a large hysteresis and distinct finite-size effects and 2 contains an antiferromagnetic chain.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XksFektg%253D%253D&md5=2bf0fca991a0785caf76b4d50049545e
      (c) Zhang, W.-X.; Xue, W.; Lin, J.-B.; Zheng, Y.-Z.; Chen, X.-M. CrystEngComm 2008, 10, 1770
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4c
      3D geometrically frustrated magnets assembled by transition metal ion and 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate as triangular nodes
      Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Xue, Wei; Lin, Jian-Bin; Zheng, Yan-Zhen; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      CrystEngComm (2008), 10 (12), 1770-1776CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Three new chiral metal-org. frameworks, (H2NMe2)[M(tzdc)]·0.5H2O [M=Co(II) (1), Mn(II) (2)] and (NH4)[Mn(tzdc)]·2.6H2O (3) (tzdc3- = 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate), have been solvothermally synthesized. In the frameworks of 1-3, the ratio of metal and tzdc3- is 1: 1. Each metal ion is chelated by three tzdc3- ligands, and each tzdc3- connects three metal ions, resulting in three-dimensional, 3-connected anionic frameworks, 1 and 2 are isomorphous, and both crystallize in the cubic space group P213. With the template of H2NMe2+ cations, the frameworks of 1 and 2 have a well-known, porous (10,3)-a network. In contrast, 3 can be obtained by replacing the H2NMe2+ with smaller NH4+ cations, which leads to a significant topol. change to a unique uniform etd (8,3) network as well as the change of the space group to P61. Magnetic studies show dominated antiferromagnetic interactions in 1-3 with θ = -46.8(1), -22.3(1) and -25.8(1) K for 1, 2 and 3, resp. Due to the triangular arrangement of the metal centers, geometrically spin-frustrated magnetism is a characteristic behavior of 1-3. For 1, spin-glassy behavior with a freezing temp. Tf of 2.4 K was distinctly obsd., and an empirical factor f = |θ|/Tf ≈ 20 > 10 indicates strong spin-frustration effect. For both 2 and 3, no obvious long-range magnetic ordering and/or spin-glassy behavior was obsd. down to 2.0 K, which might indicate the f values in them being also larger than 10. By contrast, the obsd. spin-glassy behavior above 2.0 K in 1 is probably due to the stronger magnetic anisotropy of Co(II) ion and the stronger antiferromagnetic interactions in 1.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsVOktbvO&md5=0558c4c3539290892fc8ee414aabbc12
      (d) Liu, C.-M.; Zhang, D.-Q.; Zhu, D.-B. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 4980
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4d
      1D Coordination Polymers Constructed from anti-anti Carboxylato-Bridged MnIII3O(Brppz)3 Units: From Long-Range Magnetic Ordering to Single-Chain Magnet Behaviors
      Liu, Cai-Ming; Zhang, De-Qing; Zhu, Dao-Ben
      Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (11), 4980-4987CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The coordination of MeOH and EtOH mols. was obsd. in the construction of three 1-dimensional coordination polymers composed of anti-anti carboxylato-bridged MnIII3O(Brppz)3 units [Brppz = 3-(5-bromo-2-hydroxyphenyl)pyrazolate]. The difference in these 1-dimensional complexes' structures induced by MeOH and EtOH solvents leads to the variation of the magnetic properties. The MeOH solvent product 1 [MnIII3O(Brppz)3(MeOH)3(AcO)]·0.5MeOH has a MnIII3O repeating unit with two octahedral configuration Mn(III) ions and one square-pyramid configuration Mn(III) ion, showing a long-range magnetic ordering with a Tc of 8.2 K, whereas the EtOH solvent products 2 [MnIII3O(Brppz)3(EtOH)4(AcO)] (α-phase) and 3 [MnIII3O(Brppz)3(EtOH)4(AcO)] (β-phase) are polymorphs, both having a MnIII3O repeating unit with three octahedral configuration Mn(III) ions, displaying single-chain magnet behaviors. Products 2 and 3 represent the 1st examples of polymorphs of single-chain magnets. Also, the bridging carboxylate ligand in these 1-dimensional complexes was generated by the decompn. of β-diketones via the retro-Claisen condensation reactions in the presence of strong bases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkslOltbY%253D&md5=c765008a0b4a5ae44cab62757e9b019b

      6a
      Design and synthesis of an exceptionally stable and highly porous metal-organic framework
      Li, Hailian; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, M.
      Nature (London) (1999), 402 (6759), 276-279CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
      Open metal-org. frameworks are widely regarded as promising materials for applications in catalysis, sepn., gas storage and mol. recognition. Compared to conventionally used microporous inorg. materials such as zeolites, these org. structures have the potential for more flexible rational design, through control of the architecture and functionalization of the pores. So far, the inability of these open frameworks to support permanent porosity and to avoid collapsing in the absence of guest mols., such as solvents, has hindered further progress in the field. The authors report the synthesis of a metal-org. framework, Zn4O(BDC)3.(DMF)8.(PhCl) (named MOF-5, where BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), which remains cryst., as evidenced by x-ray single-crystal analyses, and stable when fully desolvated and when heated up to 300°. This synthesis is achieved by borrowing ideas from metal carboxylate cluster chem., where an org. dicarboxylate linker was used in a reaction that gives supertetrahedron clusters when capped with monocarboxylates. The rigid and divergent character of the added linker allows the articulation of the clusters into a three-dimensional framework resulting in a structure with higher apparent surface area and pore vol. than most porous cryst. zeolites. This simple and potentially universal design strategy is currently being pursued in the synthesis of new phases and composites, and for gas-storage applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXnvFSiuro%253D&md5=68f27e20a7e4e15ea2c2f49a2a61e98a
      (b) Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295, 469
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6b
      Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
      Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b
      (c) Chae, H. K.; Siberio-Pérez, D. Y.; Kim, J.; Go, Y. B.; Eddaoudi, M.; Matzger, A. J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Nature 2004, 427, 523
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6c
      A route to high surface area, porosity and inclusion of large molecules in crystals
      Chae, Hee K.; Siberio-Perez, Diana Y.; Kim, Jaheon; Go, Yong Bok; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Matzger, Adam J.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2004), 427 (6974), 523-527CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      One of the outstanding challenges in the field of porous materials is the design and synthesis of chem. structures with exceptionally high surface areas. Such materials are of crit. importance to many applications involving catalysis, sepn. and gas storage. The claim for the highest surface area of a disordered structure is for C, at 2,030 m2 g-1 (M. Nijkamp, et al., 2001). Until recently, the largest surface area of an ordered structure was that of zeolite Y, recorded at 904 m2 g-1 (A. W. Chester, et al., 2000). But with the introduction of metal-org. framework materials, this was exceeded, with values up to 3,000 m2 g-1. Despite this, no method of detg. the upper limit in surface area for a material has yet been found. Here the authors present a general strategy that has provided a structure having by far the highest surface area reported to date. The authors report the design, synthesis and properties of cryst. Zn4O(1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate)2, a new metal-org. framework with a surface area estd. at 4,500 m2 g-1. This framework, which the authors name MOF-177, combines this exceptional level of surface area with an ordered structure that has extra-large pores capable of binding polycyclic org. guest mols., attributes not previously combined in one material.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXpsFWguw%253D%253D&md5=c5e01fc1ae8145737276e816abb3b87d
      (d) Ockwig, N. W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, O.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2005, 38, 176
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6d
      Reticular Chemistry: Occurrence and Taxonomy of Nets and Grammar for the Design of Frameworks
      Ockwig, Nathan W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, Olaf; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (3), 176-182CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      The structures of all 1127 three-periodic extended metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) reported in the Cambridge Structure Database were analyzed, and their underlying topol. was detd. It is remarkable that among the almost infinite no. of net topologies that are available for MOFs to adopt, only a handful of nets are actually obsd. The discovery of this inversion between expected and obsd. nets led the authors to deduce a system of classification taxonomy for interpreting and rationalizing known MOF structures, as well as those that will be made in future. The origin of this inversion is attributed to the different modes with which MOF synthesis was approached. Specifically, three levels of complexity are defined that embody rules grammar for the design of MOFs and other extended structures. This system accounts for the present proliferation of MOF structures of high symmetry nets, but more importantly, it provides the basis for designing a building block that codes for a specific structure and, indeed, only that structure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXksFSgsg%253D%253D&md5=13530d98a4733672738db281372887ae
      (e) Yaghi, O. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Ockwig, N. W.; Chae, H. K.; Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J. Nature 2003, 423, 705
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6e
      Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
      Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.

      6f
      Functional porous coordination polymers
      Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.
