        (b) Tian, Y.-Q.; Cai, C.-X.; Ren, X.-M.; Duan, C.-Y.; Xu, Y.; Gao, S.; You, X.-Z. Chem.—Eur. J. 2003, 9, 5673
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3b
        The silica-like extended polymorphism of cobalt(II) imidazolate three-dimensional frameworks: X-ray single-crystal structures and magnetic properties
        Tian, Yun-qi; Cai, Chen-xin; Ren, Xiao-ming; Duan, Chun-ying; Xu, Yan; Gao, Song; You, Xiao-zeng
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2003), 9 (22), 5673-5685CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Five polymorphous frameworks of cobalt(II) imidazolates, {[Co(im)2]·1/2pyridine}∞ (1), {[Co(im)2]·1/2cyclohexanol}∞ (2), [Co(im)2]∞ (3, space group I41), [Co(im)2]∞ (4, space group I41cd) and {[Co(im)2]·2/5MB}∞ (5, MB = 3-methyl-1-butanol), were prepd. by solvothermal syntheses. Of these, compd. 3 has already been synthesized in a gas-phase reaction by Seel et al. in 1969 and structurally characterized by Sturm et al. in 1975. The new synthetic strategy affords four polymorphous frameworks of cobalt(II) imidazolates (1, 2, 4, 5) of cryst. substances, of which the compd. 4 (a = b = 23.450(3), c = 12.460(3) Å, tetragonal, space group I41cd, Z = 16) is an isomorphous compd. of [Zn(Im)2]∞, which was also synthesized in a gas-phase reaction in 1980. The frameworks of compds. 1 and 2 are porous and isostructural; they have the same framework topol. that represents a novel uninodal (6,4)-net: 1: a = 18.513(4), b = 24.368(5), c = 9.2940(19) Å, orthorhombic, space group Fdd2, Z = 16; 2: a = 17.635(4), b = 27.706(6), c = 9.0810(18) Å, orthorhombic, space group Fdd2, Z = 16. The framework of compd. 5 exhibits a topol. of zeolitic structure with the unit-cell parameters: a = 24.3406(8), b = 9.4526(3), c = 24.8470(8) Å, β = 91.977(1)°, monoclinic, space group P21/n, Z = 4. The crystal structure of {[Co(i.m.)2]·1/8H2O}∞ (2') and {[Zn(i.m.)2]·H2O}∞ (3') were also detd. All polymorphous frameworks of cobalt(II) imidazolates reflect the structural features of silica (SiO2) and also exhibit different magnetic behaviors, although the imidazolates transmit the antiferromagnetic coupling between the cobalt(II) ions in all cases. However, the uncompensated antiferromagnetic couplings arise from spin-canting are sensitive to the structures: compd. 1 is an antiferromagnet with TN = 13.11 K; compds. 2-4 are weak ferromagnets (canted antiferromagnets): 2 shows a very weak ferromagnetism <15 K, 3 exhibits a relatively strong ferromagnetism <11.5 K and a coercive field (HC) of 1800 Oe at 1.8 K, and 4 displays the strongest ferromagnetism of the three cobalt imidazolates and demonstrates a TC of 15.5 K with a coercive field, HC, of 7300 Oe at 1.8 K. However, compd. 5 seems to be a hidden canted antiferromagnet with a magnetic ordering temp. of 10.6 K.

        (c) Tian, Y.-Q.; Cai, C.-X.; Ji, Y.; You, X.-Z.; Peng, S.-M.; Lee, G.-H. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2002, 41, 1384
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3c
        [Co5(im)10·2MB]∞: A metal-organic open-framework with zeolite-like topology
        Tian, Yun-Qi; Cai, Chen-Xin; Ji, Yong; You, Xiao-Zeng; Peng, Shie-Ming; Lee, Gene-Hsiang
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (8), 1384-1386CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A highly robust metal-org. zeotype was created by expansion of the zeolite topol. The novel nanoporous material [Co5(Im)10·2MB]∞ (I; HIM = imidazole, MB = 3-methyl-1-butanol) structure exhibits not only a zeolite-like topol., but also the chem. functionalizable properties of zeolites. I is monoclinic, space group P21/n, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0688, wR2 = 0.230. [Co5(Im)10·0.5EtOH]∞ is monoclinic, space group P21/n, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0561, wR2 = 0.1149.

        (d) Sunatsuki, Y.; Ohta, H; Kojima, M.; Ikuta, Y; Goto, Y.; Matsumoto, N.; Iijima, S.; Akashi, H.; Kaizaki, S.; Dahan, F.; Tuchagues, J.-P. Inorg. Chem. 2004, 43, 4154

        3d
        Supramolecular Spin-Crossover Iron Complexes Based on Imidazole-Imidazolate Hydrogen Bonds
        Sunatsuki, Yukinari; Ohta, Hiromi; Kojima, Masaaki; Ikuta, Yuichi; Goto, Yoshiyuki; Matsumoto, Naohide; Iijima, Seiichiro; Akashi, Haruo; Kaizaki, Sumio; Dahan, Francoise; Tuchagues, Jean-Pierre
        Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (14), 4154-4171CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The [FeII(H3L)](BF4)2·3H2O (1) complex was synthesized, where H3L (tris{[2-{(imidazole-4-yl)methylidene}amino]ethyl}amine) is a tripodal ligand obtained by condensation of tris(2-aminoethyl)amine and 4-formylimidazole (fim) in a 1:3 molar ratio. Starting from 1, complexes, [FeII(H1.5L)](BF4)0.5 (2, which is [FeII(H3L)][FeII(L)]BF4), [Fe(H1.5L)]BF4 (3, which is [FeII(H3L)][FeIII(L)](BF4)2), [FeIII(H3L)](BF4)3·fim·H2O (4), and [FeIII(L)]·2.5H2O (5), were synthesized and characterized. The single-crystal x-ray structure of each complex was detd. The FeII compd., 2, and a mixed valence FeII-FeIII compd., 3, involve formally hemi-deprotonated ligands, H1.5L. The structure of 3 consists of a homochiral two-dimensional assembled sheet, arising from the intermol. H bonds between [FeII(H3L)]2+ and [FeIII(L)]0. All but 5 exhibit spin crossover between low-spin (LS) and high-spin (HS) states. This is a rare case where both FeII and FeIII complexes contg. the same ligand exhibit spin-crossover behavior. Magnetic susceptibility and Mossbauer studies showed that 3 has three accessible electronic states: LS FeII-LS FeIII, HS FeII-LS FeIII, and HS FeII-HS FeIII. Compds. 1-3 show the light-induced excited spin-state trapping effect (LIESST) at the FeII sites upon irradn. with green light. The soln. magnetic properties, electronic spectra, and electrochem. properties of 1, 4, and 5 were also studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXkvFSqtb4%253D&md5=66cca931095c1cb1d133b2c896c4bd50
        (e) Ding, B.-B.; Weng, Y.-Q.; Mao, Z.-W.; Lam, C.-K.; Chen, X.-M.; Ye, B.-H. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 8836

        3e
        Pillared-Layer Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed by Robust Hydrogen Bonds. Synthesis, Characterization, and Magnetic and Adsorption Properties of 2,2'-Biimidazole and Carboxylate Complexes
        Ding, Bing-Bing; Weng, Yan-Qin; Mao, Zong-Wan; Lam, Chi-Keung; Chen, Xiao-Ming; Ye, Bao-Hui
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (24), 8836-8845CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two new isostructural complexes, [M(H2biim)3][M(btc)(Hbiim)]·2H2O (M = Co, (1); M = Ni, (2); btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate; H2biim = 2,2'-biimidazole) were synthesized and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. They present a unique structure consisting of two distinct units: monomeric [M(H2biim)3]2+ and the two-dimensional (2D) anionic polymer [M(Hbiim)(btc)]2-. In the anionic moiety, the Hbiim- monoanion is simultaneously coordinated to one metal atom in a bidentate mode and further to another metal atom in a monodentate mode. The imidazolate groups bridge the two adjacent metal ions into a helical chain which is further arranged in left- and right-handed manners. These chains are bridged by btc ligands into a 2-dimensional brick wall structure. The most interesting aspect is that the [M(H2biim)3]2+ cations act as pillars and link the anionic layers via robust heteromeric hydrogen-bonded synthons R22(9) and R21(7) formed by the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups and the H2biim ligands, resulting in a microporous metal-org. framework with 1-dimensional (1D) channels (∼11.85 Å × 11.85 Å for 1 and 11.43 Å × 11.43 Å for 2). Magnetic properties of these two complexes also were studied at 2-300 K, and their magnetic susceptibilities obey the Curie-Weiss law at 20-300 K (for 1) and 2-300 K (for 2), resp., showing antiferromagnetic coupling through imidazolate bridging. Taking into consideration the Heisenberg infinite chain model as well as the possibility of chain-to-chain and chain-to-cation interactions, the antiferromagnetic exchange of 2 is analyzed via a correction for the mol. field, giving the values of gcat = 2.296, gNi = 2.564, J = -13.30 cm-1, and zJ' = -0.017 cm-1. The microporous frameworks are stable at ca. 350°. They do not collapse after removal of the guest water mols. in the channels, and they adsorb methanol mols. selectively.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFSjt73N&md5=d1bc14298294f03086d87b4977f77011

        4a
        Dehydration-induced conversion from a single-chain magnet into a metamagnet in a homometallic nanoporous metal-organic framework
        Zhang, Xian-Ming; Hao, Zheng-Ming; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (19), 3456-3459CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        On dehydration, a 3D homometallic porous org.-inorg. framework constructed from {Co3(OH)2} chains undergoes a transition from being a single-chain magnet into a metamagnet. Apart from the loss of solvent water mols., the dehydration leaves the framework structure largely unchanged.

        4b
        Two Three-Dimensional Metal-Organic Frameworks Containing One-Dimensional Hydroxyl/Carboxylate Mixed Bridged Metal Chains: Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Magnetic Properties
        Li, Xiao-Ju; Wang, Xin-Yi; Gao, Song; Cao, Rong
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (4), 1508-1516CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two novel three-dimensional complexes formulated as [M3(bime)(μ3-OH)2(HO-BDC)2]n (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2) [bime = 1,2-bis(imidazol-1'-yl)ethane, HO-H2BDC = 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid] have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized. Both 1 and 2 exhibit similar structural frameworks resulting from one-dimensional metal/oxygen chains extended by HO-BDC but the bridging modes of HO-BDC and the coordination environments of the metal centers are different. Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the orthorhombic system, space group Pbcn, a = 18.458(2) [18.2119(12) for 2] Å, b = 12.0616(14) [11.6847(7) for 2] Å, c = 11.4859(14) [12.0688(6) for 2] Å, and Z = 4(4). Magnetic studies show that 1 displays a slow magnetic relaxation, a large hysteresis and distinct finite-size effects and 2 contains an antiferromagnetic chain.

        4c
        3D geometrically frustrated magnets assembled by transition metal ion and 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate as triangular nodes
        Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Xue, Wei; Lin, Jian-Bin; Zheng, Yan-Zhen; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        CrystEngComm (2008), 10 (12), 1770-1776CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Three new chiral metal-org. frameworks, (H2NMe2)[M(tzdc)]·0.5H2O [M=Co(II) (1), Mn(II) (2)] and (NH4)[Mn(tzdc)]·2.6H2O (3) (tzdc3- = 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate), have been solvothermally synthesized. In the frameworks of 1-3, the ratio of metal and tzdc3- is 1: 1. Each metal ion is chelated by three tzdc3- ligands, and each tzdc3- connects three metal ions, resulting in three-dimensional, 3-connected anionic frameworks, 1 and 2 are isomorphous, and both crystallize in the cubic space group P213. With the template of H2NMe2+ cations, the frameworks of 1 and 2 have a well-known, porous (10,3)-a network. In contrast, 3 can be obtained by replacing the H2NMe2+ with smaller NH4+ cations, which leads to a significant topol. change to a unique uniform etd (8,3) network as well as the change of the space group to P61. Magnetic studies show dominated antiferromagnetic interactions in 1-3 with θ = -46.8(1), -22.3(1) and -25.8(1) K for 1, 2 and 3, resp. Due to the triangular arrangement of the metal centers, geometrically spin-frustrated magnetism is a characteristic behavior of 1-3. For 1, spin-glassy behavior with a freezing temp. Tf of 2.4 K was distinctly obsd., and an empirical factor f = |θ|/Tf ≈ 20 > 10 indicates strong spin-frustration effect. For both 2 and 3, no obvious long-range magnetic ordering and/or spin-glassy behavior was obsd. down to 2.0 K, which might indicate the f values in them being also larger than 10. By contrast, the obsd. spin-glassy behavior above 2.0 K in 1 is probably due to the stronger magnetic anisotropy of Co(II) ion and the stronger antiferromagnetic interactions in 1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsVOktbvO&md5=0558c4c3539290892fc8ee414aabbc12
        (d) Liu, C.-M.; Zhang, D.-Q.; Zhu, D.-B. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 4980
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4d
        1D Coordination Polymers Constructed from anti-anti Carboxylato-Bridged MnIII3O(Brppz)3 Units: From Long-Range Magnetic Ordering to Single-Chain Magnet Behaviors
        Liu, Cai-Ming; Zhang, De-Qing; Zhu, Dao-Ben
        Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (11), 4980-4987CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The coordination of MeOH and EtOH mols. was obsd. in the construction of three 1-dimensional coordination polymers composed of anti-anti carboxylato-bridged MnIII3O(Brppz)3 units [Brppz = 3-(5-bromo-2-hydroxyphenyl)pyrazolate]. The difference in these 1-dimensional complexes' structures induced by MeOH and EtOH solvents leads to the variation of the magnetic properties. The MeOH solvent product 1 [MnIII3O(Brppz)3(MeOH)3(AcO)]·0.5MeOH has a MnIII3O repeating unit with two octahedral configuration Mn(III) ions and one square-pyramid configuration Mn(III) ion, showing a long-range magnetic ordering with a Tc of 8.2 K, whereas the EtOH solvent products 2 [MnIII3O(Brppz)3(EtOH)4(AcO)] (α-phase) and 3 [MnIII3O(Brppz)3(EtOH)4(AcO)] (β-phase) are polymorphs, both having a MnIII3O repeating unit with three octahedral configuration Mn(III) ions, displaying single-chain magnet behaviors. Products 2 and 3 represent the 1st examples of polymorphs of single-chain magnets. Also, the bridging carboxylate ligand in these 1-dimensional complexes was generated by the decompn. of β-diketones via the retro-Claisen condensation reactions in the presence of strong bases.

      6. 6
        (a) Li, H.; Eddaoudi, M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Nature 1999, 402, 276
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6a
        Design and synthesis of an exceptionally stable and highly porous metal-organic framework
        Li, Hailian; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, M.
        Nature (London) (1999), 402 (6759), 276-279CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
        Open metal-org. frameworks are widely regarded as promising materials for applications in catalysis, sepn., gas storage and mol. recognition. Compared to conventionally used microporous inorg. materials such as zeolites, these org. structures have the potential for more flexible rational design, through control of the architecture and functionalization of the pores. So far, the inability of these open frameworks to support permanent porosity and to avoid collapsing in the absence of guest mols., such as solvents, has hindered further progress in the field. The authors report the synthesis of a metal-org. framework, Zn4O(BDC)3.(DMF)8.(PhCl) (named MOF-5, where BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), which remains cryst., as evidenced by x-ray single-crystal analyses, and stable when fully desolvated and when heated up to 300°. This synthesis is achieved by borrowing ideas from metal carboxylate cluster chem., where an org. dicarboxylate linker was used in a reaction that gives supertetrahedron clusters when capped with monocarboxylates. The rigid and divergent character of the added linker allows the articulation of the clusters into a three-dimensional framework resulting in a structure with higher apparent surface area and pore vol. than most porous cryst. zeolites. This simple and potentially universal design strategy is currently being pursued in the synthesis of new phases and composites, and for gas-storage applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXnvFSiuro%253D&md5=68f27e20a7e4e15ea2c2f49a2a61e98a
        (b) Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295, 469
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6b
        Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b
        (c) Chae, H. K.; Siberio-Pérez, D. Y.; Kim, J.; Go, Y. B.; Eddaoudi, M.; Matzger, A. J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Nature 2004, 427, 523
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6c
        A route to high surface area, porosity and inclusion of large molecules in crystals
        Chae, Hee K.; Siberio-Perez, Diana Y.; Kim, Jaheon; Go, Yong Bok; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Matzger, Adam J.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2004), 427 (6974), 523-527CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        One of the outstanding challenges in the field of porous materials is the design and synthesis of chem. structures with exceptionally high surface areas. Such materials are of crit. importance to many applications involving catalysis, sepn. and gas storage. The claim for the highest surface area of a disordered structure is for C, at 2,030 m2 g-1 (M. Nijkamp, et al., 2001). Until recently, the largest surface area of an ordered structure was that of zeolite Y, recorded at 904 m2 g-1 (A. W. Chester, et al., 2000). But with the introduction of metal-org. framework materials, this was exceeded, with values up to 3,000 m2 g-1. Despite this, no method of detg. the upper limit in surface area for a material has yet been found. Here the authors present a general strategy that has provided a structure having by far the highest surface area reported to date. The authors report the design, synthesis and properties of cryst. Zn4O(1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate)2, a new metal-org. framework with a surface area estd. at 4,500 m2 g-1. This framework, which the authors name MOF-177, combines this exceptional level of surface area with an ordered structure that has extra-large pores capable of binding polycyclic org. guest mols., attributes not previously combined in one material.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXpsFWguw%253D%253D&md5=c5e01fc1ae8145737276e816abb3b87d
        (d) Ockwig, N. W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, O.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2005, 38, 176
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6d
        Reticular Chemistry: Occurrence and Taxonomy of Nets and Grammar for the Design of Frameworks
        Ockwig, Nathan W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, Olaf; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (3), 176-182CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        The structures of all 1127 three-periodic extended metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) reported in the Cambridge Structure Database were analyzed, and their underlying topol. was detd. It is remarkable that among the almost infinite no. of net topologies that are available for MOFs to adopt, only a handful of nets are actually obsd. The discovery of this inversion between expected and obsd. nets led the authors to deduce a system of classification taxonomy for interpreting and rationalizing known MOF structures, as well as those that will be made in future. The origin of this inversion is attributed to the different modes with which MOF synthesis was approached. Specifically, three levels of complexity are defined that embody rules grammar for the design of MOFs and other extended structures. This system accounts for the present proliferation of MOF structures of high symmetry nets, but more importantly, it provides the basis for designing a building block that codes for a specific structure and, indeed, only that structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXksFSgsg%253D%253D&md5=13530d98a4733672738db281372887ae
        (e) Yaghi, O. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Ockwig, N. W.; Chae, H. K.; Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J. Nature 2003, 423, 705
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6e
        Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
        Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksV2itro%253D&md5=2417c5adb0e948350d3d62350c8cd7ea

        6f
        Functional porous coordination polymers
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXktFShtLk%253D&md5=9df52e99bad3cc0db67f65551a8c154f
        (g) Duren, T.; Sarkisov, L.; Yaghi, O. M.; Snurr, R. Q. Langmuir 2004, 20, 2683
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6g
        Design of new materials for methane storage
        Duren Tina; Sarkisov Lev; Yaghi Omar M; Snurr Randall Q
        Langmuir : the ACS journal of surfaces and colloids (2004), 20 (7), 2683-9 ISSN:0743-7463.
        One of the strategic goals of the modern automobile manufacturing industry is to replace gasoline and diesel with alternative fuels such as natural gas. In this report, we elucidate the desired characteristics of an optimal adsorbent for gas storage. The U.S. Department of Energy has outlined several requirements that adsorbents must fulfill for natural gas to become economically viable, with a key criterion being the amount adsorbed at 35 bar. We explore the adsorption characteristics of novel metal-organic materials (IRMOFs and molecular squares) and contrast them with the characteristics of two zeolites, MCM-41, and different carbon nanotubes. Using molecular simulations, we uncover the complex interplay of the factors influencing methane adsorption, especially the surface area, the capacity or free volume, the strength of the energetic interaction, and the pore size distribution. We also explain the extraordinary adsorption properties of IRMOF materials and propose new, not yet synthesized IRMOF structures with adsorption characteristics that are predicted to exceed the best experimental results to date by up to 36%.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2M3gtFWquw%253D%253D&md5=0f10aca88c4253004548b2ba1dae20b3
        (h) Schlichte, K.; Kratzke, T.; Kaskel, S. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2004, 73, 81
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6h
        Improved synthesis, thermal stability and catalytic properties of the metal-organic framework compound Cu3(BTC)2
        Schlichte, Klaus; Kratzke, Tobias; Kaskel, Stefan
        Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2004), 73 (1-2), 81-88CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        The catalytic properties of the metal-org. framework compd. Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3·xH2O (BTC = benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylate) were explored. Cu2O-free powder samples of Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3·xH2O were obtained using an improved synthesis at 393 K under hydrothermal conditions. The microporous material has a high specific pore vol. of 0.41 cm3 g-1 and a pore diam. of 10.7 Å (Horvath-Kawazoe). Removal of the three copper-bound water mols. allows to access the Lewis acid copper sites. The exchange of coordinated water by substrates or solvent mols. is recognized from the color change of the compd. For chemisorbed benzaldehyde, the IR stretching frequency ν(C:O) is decreased from 1702 to 1687 cm-1. The chemisorption results in an activation of benzaldehyde for the liq. phase cyanosilylation with a reasonable yield of 50-60% after 72 h (313 K) and a high selectivity. Filtration expts. demonstrate that the reaction mechanism is heterogeneous. Coordinating solvents such as THF completely block the Lewis acid sites of the catalyst. Solvents such as CH2Cl2 or higher reaction temps. (353 K) cause decompn. of the catalyst.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Separation of hydrocarbons with a microporous metal-organic framework
        Pan, Long; Olson, David H.; Ciemnolonski, Lauren R.; Heddy, Ryan; Li, Jing
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (4), 616-619CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The microporous metal-org. framework (MMOF) of [Cu(hfipbb)(H2hfipbb)0.5] is based on a bimetallic paddle-wheel building block and comprises 1D tubular microchannels formed by the interpenetration of two identical 44 nets. The channels are hydrophobic and have the ideal size and shape to selectively adsorb C2, C3, and n-C4 olefins and alkanes.

        6j
        Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks Incorporating 1,4-Benzeneditetrazolate: Syntheses, Structures, and Hydrogen Storage Properties
        Dinca, Mircea; Yu, Anta F.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (27), 8904-8913CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The potential of tetrazolate-based ligands for forming metal-org. frameworks of utility in hydrogen storage is demonstrated using 1,4-benzeneditetrazolate (BDT2-) to generate robust, microporous materials. Reaction of H2BDT with MnCl2·4H2O and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) produces the two-dimensional framework solids Mn3(BDT)2Cl2(DEF)6 (1) and Mn4(BDT)3(NO3)2(DEF)6 (2), whereas reactions with hydrated salts of Mn2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ in a mixt. of methanol and DMF afford the porous, three-dimensional framework solids Zn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3.5CH3OH (3), Mn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3CH3OH·2H2O·DMF (4), Mn2(BDT)Cl2(DMF)2·1.5CH3OH·H2O (5), and Cu(BDT)(DMF)·CH3OH·0.25DMF (6). The method for desolvating such compds. can dramatically influence the ensuing gas sorption properties. When subjected to a mild evacuation procedure, compds. 3-6 exhibit permanent porosity, with BET surface areas in the range 200-640 m2/g. The desolvated forms of 3-5 store between 0.82 and 1.46% H2 at 77 K and 1 atm, with enthalpies of adsorption in the range 6.0-8.8 kJ/mol, among the highest so far reported for metal-org. frameworks. The desolvated form of 6 exhibits preferential adsorption of O2 over H2 and N2, showing promise for gas sepn. and purifn. applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XmtVSjtLg%253D&md5=c33a3b55e4ff31ac354ecbdd5b636120
        (k) Latroche, M.; Surble, S.; Serre, C.; Mellot-Draznieks, C.; Llewellyn, P. L.; Lee, J. H.; Chang, J. S.; Jhung, S. H.; Ferey, G. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2006, 45, 8227
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6k
        Hydrogen storage in the giant-pore metal-organic frameworks MIL-100 and MIL-101
        Latroche, Michel; Suble, Suzy; Serre, Christian; Mellot-Draznieks, Caroline; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Lee, Jin-Ho; Chang, Jong-San; Jhung, Sung Hwa; Ferey, Gerard
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (48), 8227-8231CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The metal-org. framework MIL-101 absorbs large amts. of H with a capacity of about 6.1 wt.% at liq.-N temps. - it also has the highest heat of adsorption so far (10 kJ/mol). However, MIL-101 has low hydrogen uptake at room temp. The small pores of MIL-101 play a major role in H absorption and the large empty space generated by the large cages leads to very large pores that are not as effective for H storage. In the architecture of this porous solid each intersection of the cages is occupied by a super-tetrahedron formed by trimers of Cr octahedra assembled with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate ligands.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtlGnsLjP&md5=9da229e145247a04fba4f90a912d9170
        (l) Snurr, R. Q.; Hupp, J. T.; Nguyen, S. T. AIChE J. 2004, 50, 1090
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6l
        Prospects for nanoporous metal-organic materials in advanced separations processes
        Snurr, Randall Q.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Nguyen, SonBinh T.
        AIChE Journal (2004), 50 (6), 1090-1095CODEN: AICEAC; ISSN:0001-1541. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        This is a review of current technol. for nanoporous metal-org. materials and their use in advanced sepns. processes. Most of these materials consist of metal or metal oxide vertices with org. ligands in a grid or network. These materials are prepd. in a directed-assembly process. A brief discussion of the various metal ions and kinds of linker structures available follows. Pyridine, bipyridine, carboxylic acid groups, pyrazines, carbonyl, and porphyrins have been used as org. linkers. These nanoporous metal-org. materials ca be used as sorbents, possibly for methane storage, and permselective sepn. membranes. Mol. modeling and mol. dynamics simulations can be used as a screening tool to predict possibilities of self assembly, probable product dimensions, and possible sepns. usefulness, even before the nanoporous materials are synthesized.

        7b
        Exceptional Framework Flexibility and Sorption Behavior of a Multifunctional Porous Cuprous Triazolate Framework
        Zhang, Jie-Peng; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (18), 6010-6017CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The porous metal azolate framework [Cu(etz)]∞ (MAF-2, Hetz = 3,5-diethyl-1,2,4-triazole) processes an NbO type cuprous triazolate scaffold and a CsCl type hydrophobic channel system, in which the large cavities are interconnected by small apertures with pendant Et groups. Since the Et-blocked apertures behave as thermoactivated IRIS stops for the guest mols., the gas sorption behavior of MAF-2 can be controlled by temp., in which N2 adsorption was obsd. at 195 K rather than 77 K. Single-crystal x-ray structural anal. revealed that the [Cu(etz)]∞ host framework is not altered upon N2 inclusion, confirming the occurrence of the so-called kinetically controlled flexibility. By virtue of the kinetically controlled flexibility and hydrophobic pore surface, MAF-2 can adsorb large amts. of small org. mols. but excludes H2O. As demonstrated by single-crystal x-ray structural analyses, MAF-2 shrinks, expands, or distorts its framework to accommodate the hydrogen-bonded hexamers of MeOH, EtOH, or MeCN, resp. Also, MAF-2 can also sep. benzene and cyclohexane efficiently, as its flexible scaffold can distort to a certain degree so that benzene can diffuse through the distorted apertures but cyclohexane cannot. Also, the adsorption/desorption of these org. vapors induces reversible, multimode structural transformations. Crystal structure data of multifunctional porous cuprous triazolate framework and its vapor sorption products are described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXkt1Wktbs%253D&md5=efaa38916e37d46702643c56b80637e8
        (c) Xie, Z.; Ma, L.; deKrafft, K. E.; Jin, A.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 922
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7c
        Porous Phosphorescent Coordination Polymers for Oxygen Sensing
        Xie, Zhigang; Ma, Liqing; de Krafft, Kathryn E.; Jin, Athena; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (3), 922-923CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Phosphorescent cyclometalated iridium tris(2-phenylpyridine) derivs. were designed and incorporated into coordination polymers as tricarboxylate bridging ligands. Three different cryst. coordination polymers were synthesized using a solvothermal technique and were characterized using a variety of methods, including single-crystal x-ray diffraction, PXRD, TGA, IR spectroscopy, gas adsorption measurements, and luminescence measurements. The coordination polymer built from Ir[3-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 1, is highly porous with a nitrogen BET surface area of 764 m2/g, whereas the coordination polymers built from Ir[4-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 2 and 3, were nonporous. The 3MLCT phosphorescence of each of the three coordination polymers was quenched in the presence of O2. However, only 1 showed quick and reversible luminescence quenching by oxygen, whereas 2 and 3 exhibited gradual and irreversible luminescence quenching by oxygen. The high permanent porosity of 1 allows for rapid diffusion of oxygen through the open channels, leading to efficient and reversible quenching of the 3MLCT phosphorescence. This work highlights the opportunity of designing highly porous and luminescent coordination polymers for sensing other important analytes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhs1alurrL&md5=5b4db906f93aa4289f08b1946f61662e

        Noro, S.-I.; Tanaka, D.; Sakamoto, H.; Shimomura, S.; Kitagawa, S.; Takeda, S.; Uemura, K.; Kita, H.; Akutagawa, T.; Nakamura, T. Chem. Mater. 2009, 21, 3346
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Selective Gas Adsorption in One-Dimensional, Flexible CuII Coordination Polymers with Polar Units
        Noro, Shin-ichiro; Tanaka, Daisuke; Sakamoto, Hirotoshi; Shimomura, Satoru; Kitagawa, Susumu; Takeda, Sadamu; Uemura, Kazuhiro; Kita, Hidetoshi; Akutagawa, Tomoyuki; Nakamura, Takayoshi
        Chemistry of Materials (2009), 21 (14), 3346-3355CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Introducing polar Cu-PF6 parts into a coordination framework will open new routes in the fabrication of high-performance and/or novel functional porous materials. The authors have designed and synthesized the 1-dimensional CuII coordination polymer [Cu(PF6)2(bpetha)2]n (1, bpetha = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane) with weak and flexible Cu-PF6 parts. 1 Shows the property of highly selective adsorption for CO2 and C2H2 gases, which interact with the F atoms of the polar Cu-PF6 parts. Crystallog. characterization of [Cu(PF6)2(4-mepy)4] (2, 4-mepy = 4-methylpyridine) with a basic [Cu(PF6)2(pyridine)4] structure indicates that 2 forms weak Cu-PF6 bonds at its axial sites and the polarity of the surface in 2 is higher than that in α-[Ni(NCS)2(4-mepy)4]. The axial ligand-exchanged frameworks [Cu(PF6)1.4(BF4)0.6(bpetha)2]n (3) and {[Cu(bpetha)2(DMF)2]·2PF6}n (4) enable the authors to control the onset pressure and max. adsorption amt. for targeted CO2 gases, showing the 1st case of finely controlled adsorption properties using 1-dimensional porous coordination polymers.

        9b
        Conformational Effect of 2,6-Bis(imidazol-1-yl)pyridine on the Self-Assembly of 1D Coordination Chains: Spontaneous Resolution, Supramolecular Isomerism, and Structural Transformation
        Chen, Chih-Yuan; Cheng, Pi-Yun; Wu, Hsin-Hsuan; Lee, Hon Man
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 46 (14), 5691-5699CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The achiral ligand 2,6-bis(imidazol-1-yl)pyridine (L) was used as the ditopic org. tecton for the formation of coordination polymers with Zn(II) ions. Hydrothermal reaction between L and ZnX2 (X = Br, Cl) afforded spontaneous resolved double helical motifs in ZnLCl2·0.5H2O (1) and ZnLBr2·0.25H2O (2). In the homochiral crystals of 1a and 2a, the helixes are of M-helicity, whereas, in 1b and 2b, they are of P-helicity. In contrast, solvothermal reaction between L and ZnCl2 in dried DMF afforded achiral ZnLCl2 (3a), which exhibits a zigzag polymeric motif. An achiral polymorph 3b which contains 21 helical chains was obtained in wet DMF. The formation of different 1-dimensional motifs was related to the conformations of L. All these compds. were characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental analyses, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. As revealed by TGA and powder x-ray diffraction study, the homochiral motif in 1 was stable even upon removal of guest water mols. Contrastingly, structural transformation from 3a or 3b to 1 is possible upon hydration.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Synthesis and SAR of benzamidine factor Xa inhibitors containing a vicinally-substituted heterocyclic core
        Fevig, J. M.; Pinto, D. J.; Han, Q.; Quan, M. L.; Pruitt, J. R.; Jacobson, I. C.; Galemmo, R. A., Jr.; Wang, S.; Orwat, M. J.; Bostrom, L. L.; Knabb, R. M.; Wong, P. C.; Lam, P. Y. S.; Wexler, R. R.

      17. 17
        (a) Lisnard, L.; Mialane, P.; Dolbecq, A.; Marrot, J.; Clemente-Juan, J. M.; Coronado, E.; Keita, B.; de Oliveira, P.; Nadjo, L.; Secheresse, F. Chem.–Eur. J. 2007, 13, 3525
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17a
        Effect of cyanato, azido, carboxylato, and carbonato ligands on the formation of cobalt(II) polyoxometalates: characterization, magnetic, and electrochemical studies of multinuclear cobalt clusters
        Lisnard, Laurent; Mialane, Pierre; Dolbecq, Anne; Marrot, Jerome; Clemente-Juan, Juan Modesto; Coronado, Eugenio; Keita, Bineta; de Oliveira, Pedro; Nadjo, Louis; Secheresse, Francis
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (12), 3525-3536, S3525/1-S3525/17CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Five CoII silicotungstate complexes are reported. The centrosym. heptanuclear compd. K20[{(B-β-SiW9O33(OH))(β-SiW8O29-(OH)2)Co3(H2O)}2Co(H2O)2]·47 H2O (1) consists of two {(B-β-SiW9O33(OH))(β-SiW8O29(OH)2)Co3(H2O)} units connected by a {CoO4-(H2O)2} group. In the chiral species K7-[Co1.5(H2O)7)][(γ-SiW10O36)(β-SiW8O30)(OH)Co4(OH)(H2O)7]·36H2O (2), a {γ-SiW10O36} and a {β-SiW8O30(OH)} unit enclose a mononuclear {CoO4(H2O)2} group and a {Co3O7(OH)(H2O)5} fragment. The two trinuclear CoII clusters present in 1 enclose a μ4-O atom, while in 2 a μ3-OH bridging group connects the three paramagnetic centers of the trinuclear unit, inducing significantly larger Co-L-Co (L = μ4-O (1), μ3-OH (2)) bridging angles in 2 (θav(Co-L-Co) = 99.1°) than in 1 (θac(Co-L-Co) = 92.8°). Weaker ferromagnetic interactions were found in 2 than in 1, in agreement with larger Co-L-Co angles in 2. The electrochem. of 1 was studied. The two chem. reversible redox couples obsd. in the pos. potential domain were attributed to the redox processes of Co centers, and indicated that two types of CoII centers in the structure were oxidized in sep. waves. Redox activity of the seventh CoII center was not detected. Preliminary expts. indicated that 1 catalyzes the redn. of nitrite and NO. Remarkably, a reversible interaction exists with NO or related species. The hybrid tetranuclear complexes K5Na3[(A-α-SiW9O34)Co4(OH)3(CH3COO)3]·18H2O (3) and K5Na3[(A-α-SiW9O34)Co4(OH)(N3)2(CH3COO)3]·18H2O (4) were characterized: in both, a tetrahedral {Co4(L1)(L2)2(CH3COO)3}(3: L1 = L2 = OH; 4: L1 = OH, L2 = N3) unit capped the [A-α-SiW9O34]10- trivacant polyanion. The octanuclear complex K8Na8[(A-α-SiW9O34)2Co8(OH)6(H2O)2(CO3)3]·52H2O (5), contg. two {Co4O9(OH)3(H2O)} units, was also obtained. Compds. 2, 3, 4, and 5 were less stable than 1, but their partial electrochem. characterization was possible; the electronic effect expected for 3 and 4 was obsd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXkslCruro%253D&md5=f7ffb43412262e56c5ea489c38b35d9c
        (b) Li, X.-J.; Wang, X.-Y.; Gao, S.; Cao, R. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 1508
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17b
        Two Three-Dimensional Metal-Organic Frameworks Containing One-Dimensional Hydroxyl/Carboxylate Mixed Bridged Metal Chains: Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Magnetic Properties
        Li, Xiao-Ju; Wang, Xin-Yi; Gao, Song; Cao, Rong
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (4), 1508-1516CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two novel three-dimensional complexes formulated as [M3(bime)(μ3-OH)2(HO-BDC)2]n (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2) [bime = 1,2-bis(imidazol-1'-yl)ethane, HO-H2BDC = 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid] have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized. Both 1 and 2 exhibit similar structural frameworks resulting from one-dimensional metal/oxygen chains extended by HO-BDC but the bridging modes of HO-BDC and the coordination environments of the metal centers are different. Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the orthorhombic system, space group Pbcn, a = 18.458(2) [18.2119(12) for 2] Å, b = 12.0616(14) [11.6847(7) for 2] Å, c = 11.4859(14) [12.0688(6) for 2] Å, and Z = 4(4). Magnetic studies show that 1 displays a slow magnetic relaxation, a large hysteresis and distinct finite-size effects and 2 contains an antiferromagnetic chain.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        18a
        A Novel 2D Manganese(II) Coordination Polymer Exhibiting Ferromagnetic Interaction
        Tang, Yun-Zhi; Wang, Xi-Sen; Zhou, Ting; Xiong, Ren-Gen
        Crystal Growth & Design (2006), 6 (1), 11-13CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        The reaction of the ligand rac-(R,S)-2,2'-bipyridine-3,3'-dicarboxylic acid 1,1'-dioxide [(R,S)-H2BDCD] with Mn(CH3COO)2·2H2O gives a novel 2-dimensional coordination polymer, {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} (1), which contains a dimeric Mn(II) core with dioxide (O,O atoms of carboxylate ligands) as the bridge units and exhibits ferromagnetic interaction between Mn2+ ions.

        18b
        Crystal Structure and Characterization of Manganese(II) Carboxylates: 3D Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Dobrzynska, Danuta; Jerzykiewicz, Lucjan B.; Jezierska, Julia; Duczmal, Marek
        Crystal Growth & Design (2005), 5 (5), 1945-1951CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Three mononuclear Mn (II) complexes with quinoline-2-carboxylate ion (quin-2-c), [Mn(quin-2-c)2(H2O)2]2·Hquin-2-c·2H2O (1), Mn(quin-2-c)2(EtOH)2 (2), and HbimH[Mn(quin-2-c)2Cl] (3) (HbimH+ = benzimidazolium ion), were obtained by self-assembly and structurally characterized by x-ray diffraction. Crystallog. data are given. In all three complexes the quin-2-c ions are bound to Mn in the chelate mode through a ring N and a monodentate carboxylate group. In complexes 1 and 2 the Mn ions are coordinated in the distorted octahedron with an N2O4 donor set. In the complex anion Mn(quin-2-c)2Cl-, present in the crystal of 3, the Mn ion is five-coordinated by two quin-2-c ligands and the Cl ion. The solid-state EPR spectra of 1 and 2 are characteristic of the Mn(II) ion in a distorted-octahedral geometry, whereas the spectrum of 3 is more complicated due to the zero-field splitting effect operating at lower symmetry. The EPR spectra of all complexes in frozen ROH are very similar and are characteristic of an octahedral environment around Mn. The systems of strong intermol. H bonds form 1-dimensional structures in all complexes, which are further engaged in weak C-H···O, π···π and C-H···π interchain interactions, creating the 3-dimensional networks. The IR spectra reflect the differences in the H bond systems in 1-3.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXntVOlu7s%253D&md5=037af7ded6e5cf99b9f0b0540a21dbea

        (a) Su, Z.; Cai, K.; Fan, J.; Chen, S.-S.; Chen, M.-S.; Sun, W.-Y. CrystEngComm. 2010, 12, 100
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19a
        Cadmium(II) complexes with 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoate: topological and structural diversity tuned by counteranions
        Su, Zhi; Cai, Kai; Fan, Jian; Chen, Shui-Sheng; Chen, Man-Sheng; Sun, Wei-Yin
        CrystEngComm (2010), 12 (1), 100-108CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Four new coordination polymers [Cd(L)(OAc)]·H2O (1), [Cd(L)(μ2-OH)]·H2O (2), [Cd2(L)2(μ3-SO4)(H2O)2]·5H2O (3) and [Cd(L)2]·H2O (4) with different structures and topologies were obtained by solvo/hydrothermal reactions of varied Cd(II) salts with 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (HL) and 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp). The structures of 1-4 were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction anal. and the results showed that no bpp ligands were incorporated in the resulting complexes, and more interestingly, complexes 1-3 were obtained by reactions of metal to ligand ratio of 1:1, however, when the reactions were carried out with a metal to ligand ratio of 1:2, the resulting complexes had the same structure, namely [Cd(L)2]·H2O (4). In contrast to the 2D network with 63-hcb topol. of complex 1 with acetate as terminal ligand, complex 2 is a 3D (4,6)-connected net with μ2-hydroxyl bridging group. Complex 3 is an unprecedented 3D self-penetrating (3,4,5)-connected net with each sulfate as a μ3-bridge to link three Cd(II) atoms, and complex 4 is a 3D self-penetrating (3,5)-connected net formed by two alternate chiral helical chains linking 2-fold interpenetrating 2D (4,82) nets. The results showed that the L- ligand has varied coordination modes and the counteranions have a great impact on the structure of the complexes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjs1OnsA%253D%253D&md5=1b5a829dbc12618552976f5a0bdf42c9
        (b) Su, Z.; Bai, Z.-S.; Xu, J.; Okamura, T.-A.; Liu, G.-X.; Chu, Q.; Wang, X.-F.; Sun, W.-Y.; Ueyama, N. CrystEngComm 2009, 11, 873
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19b
        Synthesis, structure and property of cobalt(II) complexes with 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid
        Su, Zhi; Bai, Zheng-Shuai; Xu, Jing; Okamura, Taka-aki; Liu, Guang-Xiang; Chu, Qian; Wang, Xiao-Feng; Sun, Wei-Yin; Ueyama, Norikazu
        CrystEngComm (2009), 11 (5), 873-880CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two novel Co(II) complexes [Co(L)(NO3)] (1) and [Co(L)(H2O)2]ClO4 (2) were synthesized by reactions of 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (HL) with the corresponding Co(II) salts, and their structures were detd. by single crystal x-ray diffraction anal. In the title complexes, the carboxylate group of L- ligand adopts a μ2-η1:η1-bridging mode to connect two Co(II) atoms, and each L- ligand acts as a 4-connector, and the Co(II) has distorted octahedral coordination geometry. In 1, one O atom of the nitrate anion links two Co(II) atoms to complete a 3-dimensional structure which is a binodal (4,6)-connected net with Schlafli symbol of (3·42·52·6)(32·42·52·64·74·8), whereas in 2, the 3-dimensional structure has topol. related to SrAl2, CeCu2 and KHg2 with Schlafli symbol of (42·63·8) and there are 1-dimensional channels filled with perchlorate anions. The nature of the counteranions, such as their shape, size and coordination ability, has a remarkable influence on the structure of the complexes. The results of the magnetic measurements showed that there are antiferromagnetic interactions between the neighboring Co(II). Also, complex 2 exhibited a modest 2nd-harmonic-generation (SHG) efficiency and anion-exchange property.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXotVyksLo%253D&md5=a860a5cecfd076529ba52977cd943bed
        (c) Su, Z.; Zhao, Y.; Chen, M.; Sun, W.-Y. CrystEngComm. 2011, 13, 1539

        19c
        Anion- and auxiliary ligand-directed synthesis of cadmium(II) complexes with 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoate
        Su, Zhi; Zhao, Yue; Chen, Min; Sun, Wei-Yin
        CrystEngComm (2011), 13 (5), 1539-1549CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Five new coordination polymers [Cd(L)(HPBDA)(H2O)] (I), [Cd2(L)2(PBDA)(H2O)2].3H2O (II), [Cd2(L)2(PBDA)] (III), [Cd3(L)2(MBDA)2(H2O)2].2H2O (IV) and [Cd2(L)(1,2,3-BTC)(H2O)].H2O (V) were obtained by reactions of 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (HL) with varied Cd(II) salts in the presence of corresponding auxiliary ligands of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2PBDA), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2MBDA) and 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid (1,2,3-H3BTC), resp. Complex I with partial deprotonated HPBDA- has 1D chain structure, while II and III are interpenetrated 3D frameworks with InS and dmc topologies, resp. Complex IV is a (4,6)-connected 3D framework, and V based on tetranuclear Cd(II) secondary building units (SBUs) is a 2D network. The thermal stability and photoluminescence property of the complexes were investigated.

        20
        Construction of Coordination Polymers with a Bifurcating Ligand: Synthesis, Structure, Photoluminescence, and Magnetic Studies
        Aijaz, Arshad; Sanudo, E. Carolina; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Crystal Growth & Design (2011), 11 (4), 1122-1134CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        A new ligand, 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DICN), was synthesized by reacting 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile with imidazole in good yields. The cyanide group hydrolyzes to carboxylic acid under solvothermal conditions in the presence of different metal salts giving rise to carboxylate and imidazole bonded coordination polymers. Seven such polymers, {[Cd(DIBA)I]·H2O}n (1), {[Zn(DIBA)(MeCOO)]·H2O}n (2·H2O), {[Zn(DIBA)(NO3)]}n (3), {[Cu(DIBA)]·H2O}n (4), {[Ni(DIBA)2(H2O)2]·3H2O}n (5), {[Co(DIBA)(OH)]·H2O}n (6), and {[Pb2(DIBA)(OH)(NO3)]}n (7) (DIBA = 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoate), were isolated. These polymers were structurally characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric (TGA), and elemental anal. Both 1 and 2·H2O form honeycomb two-dimensional (2D) layer structures that stack on top of one another to form three-dimensional (3D) networks. Complexes 3 and 6 have the same (2,4,6) connected net, while 4 is a rare 3-connected net with a 3-dimensional network. Compds. 5 and 7 have 1-dimensional (1D) and zigzag 2-dimensional polymeric structures, resp. Complex 2·H2O exhibits dynamic behavior through sliding of the 2-dimensional layers upon removal of solvent mols. in a single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) fashion. The Zn2+ and Cd2+ coordination polymers exhibit solid-state luminescence at RT. Variable temp. (2-300 K) magnetic susceptibility data on 5 are consistent with a weak ferromagnetically coupled 1-dimensional chain of Ni2+ ions. For 6, a spin-glass behavior with slow relaxation and frustration is inferred from the susceptibility data.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXisVWktrw%253D&md5=342a643bfc3f03c307e3e9057a48e1ab

        21a
        Synthesis, Structure, and Magnetic Properties of Cobalt(II) Coordination Polymers from a New Tripodal Carboxylate Ligand: Weak Ferromagnetism and Metamagnetism
        Lama, Prem; Aijaz, Arshad; Sanudo, E. Carolina; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (1), 283-290CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        A new tripodal carboxylic ligand, 5-(4-carboxy-phenoxy)-isophthalic acid, readily (cpiaH3) reacts with Co(II) salts in the presence of pyridine-based coligands under solvothermal conditions to afford four different coordination polymers, {Co2(cpia)(OH)(bipy)0.5}n (1), {[Co2(cpia)(OH)(H2O)2]·H2O}n (2), {Co1.5(cpia)(bipyethane)}n (3), and {Co1.5(cpia)(pyridine)2}n (4). All these coordination polymers were characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, TG and elemental anal. The structures of 1 and 2 can be described as a repetition of a tetranuclear core with subtle differences; two tetranuclear cores are shared by an O atom in 2, while no such bridging is present in 1. The structures of 3 and 4, however, consist of a trinuclear core extending to three-dimensional networks. Variable temp. magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that 1 exhibits ferromagnetic behavior <13 K, while 2 shows metamagnetic behavior. These interesting magnetic features are assocd. with the mixed hydroxyl/carboxylate-bridged polynuclear Co(II) clusters as subunits.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVeis7rF&md5=16c3a78273f07be12150bc5b4c600041

        A Coordination Polymer of Cobalt(II)-Glutarate: Two-Dimensional Interlocking Structure by Dicarboxylate Ligands with Two Different Conformations
        Lee, EunWon; Kim, YooJin; Jung, Duk-Young
        Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (3), 501-506CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A novel Co-glutarate, Co[O2C(CH2)3CO2] (1), was synthesized as single crystals by the hydrothermal reaction of CoCl2 with glutaric acid in the presence of KOH and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction anal., TGA, IR, UV-visible reflectance spectrometry, and SQUID measurements. The dark purple Co-glutarate crystallizes in the monoclinic system in the space group P2/c, with a 14.002(3), b 4.8064(10), c 9.274(3) Å, β 90.5(2)°, and Z = 4. The Co2+ centers are tetrahedrally coordinated to four O atoms from the dicarboxylate ligands. The anhyd.-pillared three-dimensional structure consists of infinite Co-CO2-Co inorg. layers, which are stacked by the coordinated glutarate alkyl chain along the a-axis. There are two different conformations for glutarate ligands, i.e., the gauche- and the anti-forms. These ligands reside between the inorg. layers alternatively to sep. each layer by 7.01 Å (gauche) and 6.99 Å (anti). Magnetic measurement reveals that the predominant magnetic interactions are antiferromagnetic < 14 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        24b
        Two new ferromagnetic MnII-carboxylate coordination polymers constructed from 5-tert-butyl isophthalic acid with (5/2, 15/2) and (5/2, 10/2) spin topologies
        Tian, Chong-Bin; He, Zhang-Zhen; Li, Zhi-Hua; Lin, Ping; Du, Shao-Wu
        CrystEngComm (2011), 13 (8), 3080-3086CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two new MnII coordination polymers, {[Mn4(TBIP)4(CH3OH)2]·(H2O)2}n (1) and {[Mn3(TBIP)2(HTBIP)2(Me2CHOH)2]}n (2) (H2TBIP = 5-tert-butylisophthalic acid), were synthesized by a solvothermal reaction and characterized magnetically. Single-crystal x-ray diffraction studies reveal that 1 is a three-dimensional framework, which is based on a helical chain with a new periodic -J1J1J2J2- sequence. Compd. 2 has a two dimensional layer structure constructed by trinuclear Mn(II) subunits that are extended into a 3-dimensional architecture by hydrogen bonds. Magnetic measurements indicate that both of the compds. show ferromagnetic behavior with different spin topologies. Compd. 1 is a rare even-spin center homometallic ferromagnetic compd., in which the ferromagnetism arises from the nature of carboxylate bridging modes. It is also the 1st example of a 3-dimensional homometallic ferromagnetic compd., featuring a ferromagnetic helical chain with a (5/2, 15/2) spin topol. and a 1/2 magnetization plateau. Compd. 2 is a three-spin center homometallic ferromagnetic complex with a (5/2, 10/2) spin topol. and a 1/3 magnetization plateau.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXkvVahtbc%253D&md5=cf92c1370ef5579242fbf6952991a4c0
        (c) Li, W.; Jia, H. P.; Ju, Z. F.; Zhang, J. Dalton Trans. 2008, 5350
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24c
        A series of manganese-carboxylate coordination polymers exhibiting diverse magnetic properties
        Li, Wei; Jia, Hong-Peng; Ju, Zhan-Feng; Zhang, Jie
        Dalton Transactions (2008), (39), 5350-5357CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The hydrothermal reactions of an asym. 4-(4-carboxyphenylamino)-3,5-dinitrobenzoic acid (H2cpdba), MnCl2·4H2O, or together with 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bpy) or 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy) afford three novel mol.-based magnetic coordination polymers [Mn(cpdba)]n (1), {[Mn2(cpdba)2(2,2'-bpy)2(H2O)2]·H2O}n (2) and {[Mn2(cpdba)2(4,4'-bpy)]·2H2O}n (3). Compd. 1 has a 3-dimensional acentric coordination network contg. carboxylate-bridged 1-dimensional ladder-like Mn chains with spin-canted antiferromagnetism (J = -3.51 cm-1 for the coupling along the ladder legs, and zJ' = 0.22 cm-1 for coupling along the ladder rungs), whereas compds. 2 and 3 crystallize in the centrosym. space groups P‾1 and C2/c, resp. 2 Exhibits a 1-dimensional chain structure, which is extended into a 3-dimensional supramol. network by π-π stacking interactions, while 3 features a quite complex 3-dimensional network built up from the cpdba2- and 4,4'-bpy spacers as well as the carboxylate-bridged Mn(ii) chains. Both 2 and 3 show weak antiferromagnetic coupling interactions (J = -0.55 cm-1 for 2), and a field-induced spin-flop magnetic transition can also be obsd. in 2 at ∼3.2 T at 2 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Coordination polymers of Mn2+ and Dy3+ ions built with a bent tricarboxylate: Metamagnetic and weak anti-ferromagnetic behavior
        Lama, Prem; Sanudo, E. Carolina; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Dalton Transactions (2012), 41 (10), 2979-2985CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two new coordination polymers were synthesized with Mn2+ and Dy3+ ions using a new bent ether-bridged tricarboxylic acid ligand, o-cpiaH3 (5-(2-carboxy-phenoxy)-isophthalic acid). The ligand readily reacts with a Mn2+ salt in presence of pyridine (py) under hydrothermal condition to afford a 3-dimensional coordination polymer {[Mn9(o-cpia)6(py)3(3H2O)]·H2O}n (1), that contains two types of polymeric chains. One of them is merely carboxylate bridged Mn2+ where each metal ion shows both penta- and hexacoordination. The other chain consists of carboxylate-bridging along with terminally bound pyridines providing both penta- and hexacoordination to each metal ion. When o-cpiaH3 is treated with Dy(NO3)3.xH2O under solvothermal condition, it gives rise to an unusual double layer (6,6) connected 2-dimensional coordination polymer {[Dy(o-cpia)]}n(2), where each metal ion is hexacoordinated. The double layer 2-dimensional sheets are stacked to each other in AA··· fashion through strong C-H···π interactions to generate an overall 3-dimensional supramol. architecture. Both the complexes were characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, TG and elemental anal. Variable temp. magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that 1 exhibits metamagnetic behavior while 2 shows weak antiferromagnetic behavior.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XisFOqsrs%253D&md5=2f3027c28d7723ba1808ddf2bc35aeab
        (b) Zhang, J.; Chen, S.; Valle, H.; Wong, M.; Austria, C.; Cruz, M.; Bu, Xi. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 14168
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25b
        Manganese and Magnesium Homochiral Materials: Decoration of Honeycomb Channels with Homochiral Chains
        Zhang, Jian; Chen, Shumei; Valle, Henry; Wong, Matthew; Austria, Cristina; Cruz, Maria; Bu, Xianhui
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (46), 14168-14169CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Five homochiral open-framework materials based on Mn and Mg camphorates exhibit homochiral connectivity from 1- to three-dimensions, highlighting the versatility of the synthetic system reported here. Two compds. contain a column of homochiral chains lining up the honeycomb channels of 3-dimensional metal-O frameworks, an unusual feature previously unobserved in inorg.-org. hybrids.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXht1Crur3O&md5=85df6b534d81fccd6b4e6b2ae359e7eb
        (c) Zhang, X.-M.; Wang, Y.-Q.; Song, Y.; Gao, E.-Q. Inorg. Chem. 2011, 50, 7284
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25c
        Synthesis, Structures, and Magnetism of Copper(II) and Manganese(II) Coordination Polymers with Azide and Pyridylbenzoates
        Zhang, Xiu-Mei; Wang, Yan-Qin; Song, You; Gao, En-Qing
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 50 (15), 7284-7294CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Three transition-metal coordination polymers with azide and/or carboxylate bridges were synthesized from 4-(3-pyridyl)benzoic acid (4,3-Hpybz) and 4-(4-pyridyl)benzoic acid (4,4-Hpybz) and characterized by x-ray crystallog. and magnetic measurements. Compd. 1, [Cu(4,3-pybz)(N3)]n, consists of 2D coordination networks in which the uniform chains with (μ-EO-N3)(μ-COO) double bridges are crosslinked by the 4,3-pybz ligands. Compd. 2, [Cu2(4,4-pybz)3(N3)]n·3nH2O, consists of 2-fold interpenetrated 3D coordination networks with the α-Po topol., in which the six-connected dinuclear motifs with mixed (μ-EO-N3)(μ-COO)2 (EO = end-on) triple bridges are linked by the 4,4-pybz spacers. Compd. 3, [Mn(4,4-pybz)(N3)(H2O)2]n, contains 2D manganese(II) coordination networks in which the chains with single μ-EE-N3 bridges (EE = end-to-end) are interlinked by the 4,4-pybz ligands, and the structure also features a 2D hydrogen-bonded network in which MnII ions are linked by double triat. bridges, (μ-EE-N3)(O-H···N) and (O-H···O)2. Magnetic studies indicated that the mixed azide and carboxylate bridges in 1 and 2 induce ferromagnetic coupling between CuII ions and that 3 features antiferromagnetic coupling through the EE-azide bridge. In addn., compd. 1 exhibits antiferromagnetic ordering <6.2 K and behaves as a field-induced metamagnet. A magnetostructural survey indicates a general trend that the ferromagnetic coupling through the mixed bridges decreases as the Cu-N-Cu angle increases.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXosVClu7c%253D&md5=7a1480e5845a395677b5fdf92ac348c9
        (d) Malaestean, I. L.; Kravtsov, V. C.; Speldrich, M.; Dulcevscaia, G.; Simonov, Y. A.; Lipkowski, J.; Ellern, A.; Baca, S. G.; Kögerler, P. Inorg. Chem. 2010, 49, 7764
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25d
        One-Dimensional Coordination Polymers from Hexanuclear Manganese Carboxylate Clusters Featuring a {MnII4MnIII2(μ4-O)2} Core and Spacer Linkers
        Malaestean, Iurii L.; Kravtsov, Victor Ch.; Speldrich, Manfred; Dulcevscaia, Galina; Simonov, Yurii A.; Lipkowski, Janusz; Ellern, Arkady; Baca, Svetlana G.; Kogerler, Paul
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 49 (17), 7764-7772CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The bridging of hexanuclear mixed-valent carboxylate coordination clusters [Mn6O2(O2CR)10] (R = CMe3; CHMe2) featuring a {MnII4MnIII2(μ4-O)2} core by geometrically rigid as well as flexible spacer ligands such as pyrazine (pyz), nicotinamide (na), or 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe) results exclusively in 1-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers. The formation of {[Mn6O2(O2CCMe3)10(Me3CCO2H)(EtOH)(na)]·EtOH·H2O}n (1), {[Mn6O2(O2CCHMe2)10(pyz)3]·H2O}n (2), and {[Mn6O2(O2CCHMe2)10(Me2CHCO2H)(EtOH)(bpe)]·Me2CHCO2H}n (3) illustrates a surprising preference of the interlinked {Mn6} units toward 1-dimensional coordination chains. In the solid-state, the obsd. chain propagation axes are either colinear (1 and 3) or perpendicular (2), whereby crystal packing is further influenced by solvent mols. Magnetic properties of these network compds. can be rationalized based on that the magnetism of discrete [Mn6O2(O2CR)10]-type coordination clusters with all-antiferromagnetic intramol. exchange. The weak antiferromagnetic intercluster coupling in 1, 2, and 3 follows the expected exchange coupling strength of the employed spacer linkers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpslWjsrk%253D&md5=0ec9ff01188ceada36c4c54682f0b77d
      26. 26
        (a) Kambe, K. J. Phys. Soc. Jpn. 1950, 5, 48
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26a
        Paramagnetic susceptibilities of some polynuclear complex salts
        Kambe, Kenjiro
        Journal of the Physical Society of Japan (1950), 5 (), 48-51CODEN: JUPSAU; ISSN:0031-9015.
        A quantum-mech. treatment is used to explain the temp. dependence of the paramagnetic susceptibilities of salts of Fe and Cr. Theoretical values are in good ageement with expt.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG3cXislSjtg%253D%253D&md5=41fa52aec1801e3cdff6324d22d7263c
        (b) Ren, Y. X.; Xiao, S. S.; Zheng, X. J.; Li, L. C.; Jin, L. P. Dalton Trans. 2012, 41, 2639
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26b
        Self-assembly, crystal structures, and properties of metal-2-sulfoterephthalate frameworks based on [M4(μ3-OH)2]6+ clusters (M = Co, Mn, Zn and Cd)
        Ren, Yi-Xia; Xiao, Shan-Shan; Zheng, Xiang-Jun; Li, Li-Cun; Jin, Lin-Pei
        Dalton Transactions (2012), 41 (9), 2639-2647CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Hydro- and solvo-thermal reactions of d-block metal ions (Mn2+, Co2+, Zn2+ and Cd2+) with monosodium 2-sulfoterephthalate (NaH2stp) form six 3-dimensional coordination polymers featuring cluster core [M4(μ3-OH)2]6+ in common: [M2(μ3-OH)(stp)(H2O)] (M = Co (1), Mn (2) and Zn (3)), [Zn2(μ3-OH)(stp)(H2O)2] (4), [Zn4(μ3-OH)2(stp)2(bpy)2(H2O)]·3.5H2O (5) and [Cd2(μ3-OH)(stp)(bpp)2]·H2O (6) (stp = 2-sulfoterephthalate, bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine and bpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane). All these coordination polymers were characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric and elemental anal. Complexes 1-3 are isostructural coordination polymers with 3-dimensional frameworks based on the chair-like [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ core and the quintuple helixes. In complex 4, there exist double helixes in the 3-dimensional framework based on the chair-like cluster cores. Complex 5 possesses a 2-fold interpenetration structure constructed from boat-like cluster core and the bridging ligands stp and bpy. For complex 6, the chair-like cluster cores and stp ligands form a 2-dimensional (4,4) network which is further pillared by bpp linkers to a 3-dimensional architecture. Magnetic studies indicate that complex 1 exhibits magnetic ordering <4.9 K with spin canting, and complex 2 shows weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(II) ions with g = 2.02, Jwb = -2.88 cm-1, Jbb = -0.37 cm-1. The fluorescence studies show that the emissions of complexes 3-6 are attributed to the ligand π-π* transition.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xitl2iu7k%253D&md5=3f5dbd54c239e740db3231dee97408cc
      27. 27
        Yang, Q.; Zhao, J.-P.; Hu, B.-W.; Zhang, X.-F.; Bu, X.-H. Inorg. Chem. 2010, 49, 3746
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        New Manganese(II) Azido Coordination Polymers with Nicotinic/Isonicotinic Acids as Coligands: Synthesis, Structure, and Magnetic Properties
        Yang, Qian; Zhao, Jiong-Peng; Hu, Bo-Wen; Zhang, Xiao-Feng; Bu, Xian-He
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 49 (8), 3746-3751CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The reactions of MnII ions with azido ligands in the presence of nicotinic/isonicotinic acids gave two manganese(II) azido coordination polymers, [Mn3(L1)2(N3)4]n·nH2O (1) and [Mn2(L2)(N3)3]n (2), where L1 = nicotinate and L2 = isonicotinate, with different topol. structures. Complex 1 consists of 2-dimensional azido-MnII planes, which are further linked by L1 to form a 3-dimensional framework with unprecedented 3,6-connected 4-nodal net topol., and complex 2 presents an unprecedented 3,4,6-connected 6-nodal 3-dimensional azido-MnII structure with L2 as the coligand. Magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal dominant antiferromagnetic coupling existing in 1 and 2. Complex 1 is a spin-competitive system and enters into a weak ferromagnetic-to-magnetic phase transition at the crit. temp. of 6 K due to spin canting. Complex 2 is an antiferromagnet and exhibits field-induced spin-flop behavior.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjslalsrc%253D&md5=27a821ebd28b3177865c89bccfe70479
      28. 28
        Banerjee, R.; Furukawa, H.; Britt, D.; Knobler, C.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 3875
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        28
        Control of Pore Size and Functionality in Isoreticular Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks and their Carbon Dioxide Selective Capture Properties
        Banerjee, Rahul; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Britt, David; Knobler, Carolyn; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (11), 3875-3877CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Five new cryst. zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), ZIF-78 to -82, were prepd. from zinc(II) nitrate and mixts. of 2-nitroimidazole and five different functionalized imidazoles and were found to have the GME topol. These structures, along with three previously reported GME ZIFs, constitute a series of highly porous materials with Brunauer-Emmet-Teller surface areas ranging from 620 to 1730 m2/g. The pore diams. and apertures vary incrementally from 7.1 to 15.9 Å and 3.8 to 13.1 Å, resp., and the functionalities decorating the pores vary from polar cyano- and nitro- groups to nonpolar alkyl groups. The variability expressed in these materials makes them highly attractive for study as gas-sepn. media. Selectivity values calcd. for sepn. of CO2 and CH4 predict that the ZIFs with polar functionality, ZIF-78 (10.6:1) and -82 (9.6:1), retain CO2 gas to a greater degree than the other members of the GME series and BPL-activated carbon. These predictions are borne out in dynamic breakthrough studies, which confirm the increased capacity of ZIF-78 and -82 and demonstrate the promise of this class of materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXisFans7s%253D&md5=5fba32f296b7f0cf32e22fa84b98af89
